text: Бутылка в московс& пабе Брюгге. Интерес& кисло-сл вкус с фруктов& оттенка& и легкой горчинк& в послевк& Карбони& слабая.

7/V/17 - sample @ the brewery (Toer de Geuze) - BB: n/a (2017-587) Thanks to ElManana+1 for sharing the beer!
Clear copper orange beer, creamy white head, unstable, bit adhesive. Aroma: woody, funky, bit cheesy, some caramel. MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: pretty sour, caramel, bit sweet, lemony, lime peel, sugary touch. Aftertaste: pretty sourish, caramel, sweet, bit funky, cheesy finish. Actually one of the better faros Ive tasted so far. Still very sour, which is nice!

Robe ambrée, rousse, translucide. Légère écume. Nez sur le sucre, pointe de lambic, impression de thé. Bouche sucrée (candi), très légère acidité, saveur type Ice-Tea, fort sucré. Très faiblement carbonaté. Faro commercial fort sucré.

Sampled from 0.25 l bottle from Belgiuminabox.com, best before August 2016. Murky, brownish red with a thin, soapy, slowly diminishing, white head. Sweetish, slightly sourish, a bit fruity and a little woody aroma of rotten lemon, vinegar, sugar and some wood. Very sweet, slightly sourish and a bit fruity taste of rotten lemon, apples, lots of sugar, some wood and hints of leather, followed by a short, slightly tart, a bit dry finish. Medium body, quite astringent and a bit effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Way too sweet, almost artificially so, unpleasant aroma, overall hardly drinkable.
Un Faro assez basique, qui allie notes acidulées, caramel et pointe de lambic. Bouche plutôt dominée par le sucre.

Bottle @ home, 3 years. Pours a dark amber to brown color with a minimal head. Aroma is dry an slightly sweet with cherries, toast, slight barnyard and vinegar. Taste is is rather sugar sweet, medium bodied. Notes of cherries, sugar, acetic acid, lemon and hints of barnyard. Finish is dryer and lemon acidic with lingering sugar, cherries and strawberries.
Smell of barnyard funk, green bottle skunk. Taste has alot of sugar mixed fruit in it. Pours with no head dark yellow in color. Decent beer.

Bottle. Pours in dark amber body with no head at all. Aroma has sugar sweet, cream, toasty character. Taste has high, very high sugar sweetness upfront with some fruity touches after the end. Oh god, so sweet. Body is thick, oily, sweet, low carbonation.

Bottle 25cl.
@ Cerveceria Internacional, Seville, Spain.
A: Hazy brown.
T: Sugar, sour, fruity.

250ml bottle (thanks martjoobolut). Slightly hazy brown color. Small size, bubbly beige head, stays as a ring. Fruity, peach, sweet, sour, vinegar in aroma. Sweet, jammy, peach, apricot in taste. Sugary and apricots in aftertaste. Way too sweet for me, but not bad.
Bottle (from belgiuminabox). Pours brownish. Aroma is acidic, sugar, vinegar. Flavor is sweet and sour, some vinegar. Overall: weird, but i kind of like it.

Bottle shared by Mart. Hazy brown amber beer, small head. Nose is tart, fruit, barnyard, plums and sugar. Flavor is very sugary and sweet, fruitiness takes a backseat to the sugar, there are some tart notes in the finish, but oh boy is this sugary. Not overly sticky though.

Appearance: Slightly hazy brown, small amount of fizzy, off-white head.
Aroma: Sweet apples. Plums.
Taste: Fruits, plums, apples. Quite sweet, though still some tartness.
Bought: Beers of Europe, 250 ml, £1.39
Info: 25/3-2016, BB: 20/8-2016

Bottle, picked up at Binnys! Pours quite hazy orange, small beige head, dissipates slowly, decent lacing. Aroma is sweet funk, candi sugar, carmelized sugars, hints of Brett and barnyard. Flavor is very sweet and lightly funky. You can almost feel supersaturated sugar crystals going down your throat. Medium body, low carbonation. Pour it over ice cream? Dont drink it. You will die of diabetes. Oh well, 38 more beers to find to succeed in getting 10 of each style before 10,000 rates.

Aroma - danky farm, brown sugar, and some spice.
Appearance - dark-reddish brow with a small beige head
Taste - funky barnyard and rich sugars
Palate - medium body, soft carbonation

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, April 2014 Not So Fools Tasting (rating backlog) Pours brown. Nose is sweet cherry and raspberry and some toffee. Taste is very much the same with some balsamic vinegar and soap, i cant imagine saying something that tastes of vinegar and soap tasting nice but this did.

25 cl bottle @ home, BBE 18.09.2014
Aroma is nice combination of earthy sourness and sugary sweetness. Flavour is tartish with grapefruit, sweet sugary maltiness and some fruits. Interesting and better than I expected.
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye..Pour is clear gold with a fading ring..Nose is cardboard, sweet, caramel, ...Taste is sweet, cola, musty, caramel,

Overwhelming sweet aroma and taste. Have to get used to this. Slight opaque yellow, small white foam ring. Caramel and sugar aftertaste. (Luik 201507)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: hay, grass, earthy, barnyard, 
Appearance: cloudy golden, slight white head
Taste: apples, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, 
Palate: medium body, thin feel, soft carbonation, 

Not my favorite take on the style
Rouge foncer avec presque pas de col. Larôme de pomme et sucré. En bouche cest fruité avec plein de pomme. Un peu trop sucré.

A dark reddish brown coloured beer with a weak off white head. A winey, vinegary aroma, red wine and balsamic, plus a ketchup like fruitiness and a woody element in the background. Medium mouthfeel. A balanced sweet and sour taste, sweet red fruit, toffee apple, and tomato! This, then brings in the sourness, balsamic and red wine. It's like a fizzy sherry!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nice golden pour mid white head with rolling bubbles along the glass. Small nothin like it taste loads of flavor , Apple pie, honey, sweetness with yeast notes. The Apple stays on the palet like drinking juice.
Pour is the color of apple pie filling with a small white head. Aroma is tart and funky but taste like brown sugar and apples. A very good beer that is smooth and full of fall flavor.

bottle courtesy of and shared with Kermis.
Very thin white head. Sweet with a little sournes.. Not great.

Bottle shared with Deanso. Pours a murky brown with a ring tan head. Aroma of nasty typical chapeau sickly lambic, sugar, stagnant funk. Flavor is heavy sweet, a touch of acidity behind. Over light bodied with soft carbonation. Not good, but Ive had worse chapeaus
*Old rating, best before 26/10/13.  Schön holzig-süßliches Bier. Nette Säure mit angenehmer frischer Holznote. Lecker, fruchtig, schöne Kandisnote. Spannend!

Bottle, 25cL. Home. Trade with @Jaghana. A beautiful clear golden orange beer with a big white head ; average retention. Aroma of acid fruits, apple, (light) wood. Heavy sweet, medium lasting acid. Light body, watery texture, soft carbonation, medium sweet finish, acid note. Overall, too much sugar... Unpleasant, I didnt like this one... Born to be wild but turned into sugary foggy landscape.

25cl bottle bb¿11/15?, merci Calisky. Brackish fizzy yellow pour. Smells like half a can of Red Bull poured over a mouldy apple cake: both candy sugar and artificial sweetener (saccharin, sucralose?) cover and ruin the lovely natural funky fruit sourness that anyone who tries De Trochs Oude Lambiek from rare source knows is there. Moulding peaches and brackish cider join the sugar party (20% of the bottle) in taste, whilst stale citric lemonade surfaces to whip up fizzy acid bubbles against the roof of the mouth, all insiduously conjuring up gastric ebullience like a Bailey&Tonic icecube timeclock. - Quite unbalanced, working with a quality base lambiek and hence tragically telling of the conflict of (commercial vs restorative) interests this brewery subsists on/against. De Trochs Chapeau line remains the 80s Radler of the lambiek world, a hard to rate historical attraction in itself.
Sugar cane and some lambic aroma. Sourness is completely voided by added sugar. For those who have a sweet tooth.
Bière très sucré avec un goût fruité. Bière plate. Le goût névolue pas. Un peu trop sucré pour une faro
Flat beer with a good taste of candy sugar. This beer can go well at the end of à meal, with a dessert or something sweet.

Trotz der niedrigen Wertung hatte ich Hoffnungen. Pustekuchen. Dieses Piwo ist ein dahingeklatschtes Lambic mit billigstem Raffinadezucker zu Tode gezuckert. Es gibt Aromen, diese werden jedoch von der Süße so vernichtet wie es bei deutschen Radlern zumeist der Fall ist.

Bottle from trade with Calisky - thank you, Fred. The beer has got a light hayz light amber colour with an low head and medium body. Aroma of vinegar and rotten mandarinas. Taste of vinegar, rotten fruits, bread and basement. Unpleasant beer, didnt enjoy it.
Bottle at home. Pours deep golden color, white head. Aroma is fruity, lemon, citrusy, raspberries. Taste is sweet, medium sour, artificial fruity, lemon, berries.

Bottle: Chestnut orange color with a minimal beige head. Nose is lightly vinous, vinegar, and oak. Taste is more on par with the faro sugar sweetness that (as a faro novice) I expected. A nice balanced sweetness and mild tannins. Drinks just fine.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2015 Couleur dorée orangée, bonne mousse blanche. Bon nez fruité pomme acidulé/aigrelet. Gout vieilles pommes, pommes sucrées, un peu acidulé sur la fin. Pas mal
peut être juste un peu trop sur le sucré et pas sur le subtil aigre/acidulé pour être vraiment bien

Bottle at home. Pours cloudy reddish brown. nose is dark fruit juice and hint of gueuze. Tastes of cherry juice, molasses, musty, grape skins, sweet tea, and some gueuzey undertones. Pretty sweet but not cloying. Could use more acidity to punch it up some.

375ml bottle shared by Anndiesel. Murky deep grey brown body. Significant floaties in my glass. An interesting mix of sour and sweet brown malt in the aroma. I really like the deep muddled sugar tones, and think this is a refreshing beverage...just one that shouldnt command premium prices. Not unlike a really mild Oud Bruin at times. Sweet and refreshing. OK.
Sweet, artificial faro since 1991, with a relatively dark colour and sweet character of brown sugar and caramel candy, lambic character weak and suppressed as always in this range.
Zeer lekker faro-bier, ik vond het een meevaller, zeker bij warmere temperaturen buiten.

Flat, no head, brown lambic with barley, wheat and 20% sugar candy. Aroma like prunes. Sweet taste. Don't like.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from bottle into snifter. Pours a lightly hazy orange with 1 finger white head. Head dissipates fairly quickly, but leaves quite a bit of lacing. Aroma - apple cider vinegar, white grape, and a really subtle note of funk underneath. Taste - obviously sweet, but also peach and brown sugar. Theres very little funk on the palate either. Finish is long and sweet.

25cl bottle thanks to allmyvinyl.
Appearance - cherry red with no head. 
Nose - dark cherries or blackcurrants, with a wild yeast edge. 
Taste - sweet fruit again, black fruits as before.
Palate - close to medium bodied with a sweet middle texture and a slightly cloying finish.
Overall - you would swear there was some blackcurrant in there. Quite sweet but despite all that, quite pleasant.
250ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours clear brown, no head. Aromas of sugar, sherbet, blackcurrant. Taste is sweet, light sour fruit. Sweet finish.
Bottle at Craigs. Pours deep brown, sweet toffee and caramel, dry and fruity.

Bottle. Dark brown, flat pour. Aroma is grainy, caramel, molasses, candi, light rotten woody notes. Taste is sweet, very caramel, flat Dr Pepper. Palate is sweet, low carb, almost flat. Its gross, but drinkable (sort of).

Bottle (250 ml). Shared by JulienHuxley, thanks! Murky amber/brown with a small ring of off-white foam and no lacing. Aroma is of brown sugar, very light balsamic notes and caramel. Taste is also of brown sugar, light acidic, balsamic notes and light fruits. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Its awful but considering that its from Chapeau and thats its also a Faro, it aint that bad.

Murky light brown, thin filmy ringed off white head. Balsamic vinegar offness. Soft soapiness to the initial taste, sweet floralness and murkiness that thins out to the finish. Dishwater mouthfeel, grubby tart linger. Bottle, Cheers Stu666, April Not So Fools Tasting

bottle at home ... deep brown ... thin white lacing ... soft soft tofee ... dry fruits ... dark balsamic tone nose ... very sweet fruits ... soft fruit ... light tartness ... little balsamic... interesting but not me

Shared a 25cl bottle from Delheize (Belgium). Pours a clear brown colour with no head or lacing. Aroma is grassy, fruity and dough. Flat carbonation and light body. Taste is medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour. Overall, a not so balanced beer with no much remarkable about it.
Bottle at home. Very poor. No head, very sweet sickly, chocolaty aroma. Almost no sourness but overpoweringly sweet palate. Avoid.
Very dark red, almost black, with no head. Sour farmyard aroma. Sweet, a bit too much. Reasonably smooth, but bland. A big disappointment.

reddish brown colour, practically no head, just some off-white lacing; aroma and taste of fruits, some grain, wine, maybe yeast and sugar - would be much better faro with a bit less sugar and more intensive sourness

Bottle @ zytholoog 
2008 vintage
Pours dark brown ( very dark for a faro ) 
Realy sweet smell 
Very sugary ( older kind of sugary , bit caramelized ) still ok , but no complexity or sourness

25cl bottle. Dark red and brown with almost no head. Nose : apple, caramel, cream, cooked fruits. Sip : medium body with low carbonation. Cloying sweet and cooked fruit notes. Sour and cloying sweet till the end. Buerk.

Bottle at home, from BOE, 05/09/13.
Pours mahogony brown with a thin white swirl atop the glass.
Nose is woody, burnt toffee, bitter orange, earthy, light medicinal notes.
Taste is sweet sugary caramel sludge, background fruits, brown sugars.
Medium bodied, soft carbonation, sweet sugars and caramel kick in during the finish.
Drinkable - just,  but too sweet, about time De Troch sacked the sugar fiend who turns all of their beers into syrupy sludge ! It started off fairly promisingly with looks and nose !
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
Aroma- Sweet n sour fruity, Very much like a fruity wine
Appearance- Hazy amber with a thick white head
Flavor- Sweet, dark fruit with a slight tart aftertaste, no bitterness at all, slight caramel and oak. Very good!

Brown caramel colour, no head. Aroma of caramel, brett and artificial sweetener. Sweet flavour, light sour note, lots of caramel. Sweet finish, sweetener, light sour note. Not the best Faro out there, but quite decent and certainly better than I was expecting!
(From 25cL bottle @ DutchDrebus place. Thanks for sharing, Rene!)

02/08 A 0.25l bottle @Pater Marcus, Budapest. Only my second faro, unbelievable, but dont have more available in Croatia, nor actually much elsewhere. It poured clear reddish brown body with almost no head. Sour, lightly stale and brown sugar aroma. Flavor is sweet, but vinous, brown sugar/molasses, raisins, gets dryer and more sour towards the end. Some stale off note I didnt like. Medium bodied, nicely rounded. Decent sugary and acidic finish. Quite decent one, although I remember the other faro I had as much better.

Pours a brown, almost cola color with a small head that fades away. 
 
The aroma is sweet with some brown sugar, there is some detectable funkiness and lemony character. Its and odd aroma neither unpleasant or appealing. 
 
The flavor is very sweet, lemony, tart, and all together much too soda like. There is a little bit of woodiness. 
 
Just way overly sweet.
Gedronken met joes, benzai, tinus en dutchdrebus, bruine kopere kleur, beige schuimkraag, ruikt zoet, fruitig, muf, smaakt te zoet, fruitig,
Bottle @ home thx to benzai. Copper to brown colour with no head. Smells sourish, weird. Tastes very sweet, malty. Medium body, soft carbo.

Bottle shared with Joes, Dutchdrebus, Ansjelaah and Martinus. Clear reddish color, virtually no head. Sourish aroma, but sweet taste. A bit artificial even. Oh no, I dont like this. Low to average body, low carbonation.

375mL bottle, pours a murky dark amber brown with little head, but tons of sediment floating about. Aroma is mostly candied sugar, with a touch of acidic notes - suggesting an intensely sweet flavour. The flavour confirms this, but there is more than just sweet, with some lightly sour notes to balance. The sour is almost akin to a Flemish sour, but without the elegance. Carbonation is almost non-existent, with a flat body. Overall, balanced between sweet and sour pretty well, with no cloying sweetness as usual with the other Chapeau fruit "lambics". All in all, not as bad as I thought, though certainly far from a real lambic (faro or otherwise).

Drank from the bottle but poured some on the ground to check the colour, brownish amber with little in the way of head. Expected the very worst from this beer considering my previous experiences with their sweetened geuze.
Smell is extremely sweet, almost hard to comprehend & the same goes for the taste. Pure candy sugar syrup, the initial feeling is that of pure shock, very thick honey, syrup, thick coca-cola / soda sensation, dark fruit syrup and some very sweet wood. Super thick caramel. Carbonation is nice. 
Unimaginably chemical and so sweet that even I am taken back but this was actually enjoyable even if not in a beer way. 
This is good soda syrup or something like that. 
(25 cl. bottle // drank straight from the bottle @ bus stop with Artiom // purchased from Willems en Zoon // BBF 26/10/2013)

Bottle. No head to speak of. The aroma is very interesting and complex. Candied sugar, honey, mead, sherry, notes of cherries and plums, dried fruit. Only vague hints of vinegar and green apples, some interesting notes of blue cheese and French mustard. Quite a vinous, honeyish taste that should appeal to both drinkers of sherry and of Polish meads. Low carbonation. Unfortunately it is way too sweet. While the dryish, slightly astringent finish balances the sip initially rather well, after swallowing there is still a cloying feeling left. Fix that and this will be an awesome brew.

Bottle:
Smaller sized and quickly changing ashy white head on top of a clear dark ruby colored beer.
Aromas has lots of wood, some raisin, some brown sugars, hint if something whiskey alike, dust.
Flavours of sweets and bitters, brown sugars, wood, sticky, malts, raisin, figs, some dusty wood and toast. Much alike the aroma.
Low carbo, soft sparkling smooth mouthfeel, medium body and a light creamy texture.
I like this beer. Though its not deep, complex and sour, its crisp and easy drinkable. One of the better beers from De Troch.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Sort of a strange brew. Bottle from oblivion. Nose is raw cane sugar, brown sugar, and maybe a vegetable like aroma. Hmmm.... Pour is brown and clear. No head or lacing. No carbonation. Syrupy flavors and raw sugar. A touch of tartness. I dont really know what to think about this. It isnt bad but it is just strange to the point of indifference.

Bottle. Pours murky copper brown with no head at all. Clear vinous aroma. Mild vinous onset, giving way to dominant, sweetish honey notes. Dryish and vinous aftertaste. Rather unbalanced. Nothing impressive, but clearly one of the two varieties from De Troch which are drinkable. The others should be delegalised ASAP.
Bottle. Pours clear brown with quite some bubbles and no head. Aroma is sweet candy, honey, mead, red wine. Flavor is honey, mead. A bit too sweet, and too mead-like, otherwise pretty good.

I dont know why I do this to myself....Bottle from De Troch Brewery. It pours clear deep brown, with a tiny, bubbly off-white head. The nose is tangy, ice tea, vanilla, caramel and light vinegar. The taste is caramel, sweet apple, pear, tangy, artificial sweetness, ice tea, cherry, faint sourness and boiled sweets, with a short finish. Light-medium body and lowish carbonation. Actually has a bit of sourness to it. On hindsight this isnt the worst faro I have hadnot a drain pour anyway.

bottle from beer planet.
clear brown, smooth white head.
nice fruity sour aroma, faint stale hops, faint barnyard.
flavor is pretty acetic, medzine cabinet, fruity sweetness, While sweetened, the lambic flavor comes clean and crisp, and the sweetness does not ruin the lambic as i think it does in some other sweetened lambics.

First Faro rating! Bottle from Knightly. Amber pour with a small, quickly fleeting white head. Nose of sugar sweet vanilla extract, toasted malts, mild yeast funk, over ripening grapes and old socks. Definitely a weird combo of aroma. Flavor of sugary grape juice with some very light sourness and lemon on the back end. Sweet, sugary body with light carbonation. Almost unbearable.

I was expecting a sweetened lambic here but was disappointed... this is in fact the first lambic I havent raved over. Simpler than I thought this style could get, the candi yeast covers everything in the aroma, flavour, and finish, and you get a slight sourness in the back but its way too small. Not even "out there", which must be hard to do for such a strange style. I guess it would be fine with desert, but it doesnt feel exquisite, just lame, so have it with a chocolate bar, not French pastry.

$5 bottle with a pop cap and cork too....
A: Pours a transparent brown color with a tiny tiny head that dissipates immediately

S: Overripe/almost rotting fruit (in a good way), champagne, raisin, fig, dates. Pretty much an overall apple cider vinegar nose

T: Whoa, extremely sweet. Lots and lots of fruits, overripe and dark. Lots of champagne yeast notes, and very very vinous in general. Also tart fruit

MF/D: smooth feel to it, low carbonation, and anything but dry.

Notes: Possibly the most unique beer Ive had to date
Bottle 4,75%. Dark brown with tiny beige head. Aroma is malt, little sour, little citric and candy sugar. Flavour is malt, candy sugar, little sour, sweet and sugar.
Bottle @ home.... It pours hazy dark amber with floats the head is small....The aroma is sour, caramel and fruity..... The flavor is caramel, dark fruits, yeast and sour.....

Bottle shared by drabmuh. Thanks Matt!

The beer is mostly clear and see-through, with small chunks of sediment wandering aimlessly throughout the beer. The color is a light orange sunburst. The beer has a small head that leaves just a touch of lacing on the glass. The aroma is sweet and fruity, like a fruit juice. The beer tastes very sweet, though I suppose this was the intention. Personally, I cant fathom why one would take a sour beer and intentionally make it sweeter. To each their own. Surprisingly, the sweetness is not as cloying as I predicted. The body is medium-thin with a low level of carbonation. It was a fun experience, but I much prefer the traditional lambics over faros. From an objective standpoint, this was a pretty good beer.
Unclear brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet malty and dark sugar. Flavor is quite sweet and light acidic. Sweet finish. 190712

Clear mahogany in colour with a thin off-white head, light lacing.  The aroma is on the sweet side, berries, sour notes.  The flavour is again sweet but expected, fruit, sourness, with some caramel.  Sweet mouthfeel, medium/light body, medium/light carbonation.  Finishes long, sweet.

Since its a Chapeau, your expectations arent all that high coming in.  Since they produced a drinkable starter gueuze they do have the ability to make a decent lambic.  Theiri faro is fine, not in the upper echelon for sure but a good mid range faro.

375ml bottle obtained in a trade with TheCheeseMan, thanks Dan.
Opened on September 3, 2010.
No date but have had the bottle for 3 years.

250ml bottle. Seet malty aromas. Pourdark copper, nice tan head, some lacework. Light body, average carbonation. Taste is really sweet, no hint of sourness. To sweet for me, as i expect more tart in a faro.
Wow, this beer is too sweet. A little bit sourness of the lambic, but it disappears in the overwhelming sweetness of sugars and sweeteners. Very bad faro!
Bottle at Delirium Tremens, BrusselsHazy brown color, small sized head. Some aroma of rotten apples. Typical Chapeu flavor, sweet-fruity non-beery thingy.
12.7oz Bottle Pours out a rust orange topped with a small ring of a head. Aroma was very sweet some pitfruit along with lots of sugar. Taste was more of the sweetness and a little fruit.
basement aromas, spruce, vanilla, caramel, amber, sparkling, minimal head, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, sticky, flat,
Amber, not much head.  Aroma is a dark fruit, mushroomy, dank funk.  Taste is quite sweet, and of dark fruit candy.  Theres a bit of sourness, but the sweetness hides much of it.
Bottle, pours a tannish coloour, the taste is way to sweet, not very pleasant to drink, you can taste the faro in there but its not pleasant

Bottle 25cl, a cloudy amber brown beer with low head. nose is very nice near to a oude bruin with brettanomyce notes as well as sweet notes. Aroma is nice on lambic and sour notes but too sweet, should be just a bit less sweet to be really great.

Pours an awesome rusty orange with little bubbles. Smells very sweet, nothing short of brown sugar and dried oranges - altogether a bit like a dry wine. Tastes like honey dew and tangerine, the sweetness was pretty high, and stayed around until the tangy smooth finish. Some would say that this is too sweet, but still enjoyable nonetheless.

Bottle, at the brewery. Its a dark reddish brown beer topped by a minimal sized beige head. A bit weak on the aroma, with cellar, brown sugar, and a touch of something spiced. The flavor is very cellary and barnyardish, some sugar too of course. Medium body. Metallic finish with some dirt cellar notes. A decent one, but far from the most interesting faro Ive had. 110501
On  tap at the brewery at Tour De Geueze. Brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is sugar, malt, cellar notes. Flavour is sweet, sugar, earth, yeast, cellar notes. Nice and sweet  beer.

From bottle @ Brouwerij De Troch. Dark ruby body, topped by a ring of beige bubbles. Sweet refined sugar aroma  with notes of red berries. Taste has a rounded sweetness with notes of dried fruits, added by a suitable acidity. Notes of flowers and herbs. Quite filling. Hints of caramel in the ending.  A  nice one.

Medium beige head. Brown body. Earthy funky sugary aroma with waxy notes. Dry-sweet earthy old cellar and barnyard taste. Mid-bodied. Mild mouthfeel with acid bite. Dryish-alcoholic earthy floral herbal aftertaste with cellar notes. Nice. Drinkable and unusual. (0.33l bottle at the brewery.)

I like the dusty funkiness of the aroma, there is some nose-curling sourness that arises, leather, prune. Looks good (rich brown, not too clear) and maintains carbonation well. Obviously quite sweet (prune, raisin) with a sour tinge, but not a complicated flavor and gets treachly soon enough. Still, about average score and drinkable again if in a sour beer pinch (otherwise, why bother though...?)
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: (375ml bottle) rich ruby-amber with medium sized lasting clear bubbles. Nose of moss, dusty, prune, vinegar, wood, and sugar. Taste is very sweet, oak, mild tartness from a vinegar note thats not acidic, caramel and light tangerine. Medium carbonation and body. One of the better De Troch Ive had.
Bottle at the source, Tour de Geuze 2011.  Clear amber color.  Aroma and taste of caramel.  Sweet stuff.

12.7oz bottle into my Rodenbach Grand Cru glass....Light tan head, not much carbonation. The beer is a dark coca-cola, really likes like a pop more than a beer...nice aroma, vinegar, wood, tart cherries, just not overly strong wish it was more of a pucker and there is a weird musky finish...The taste is insanely weird, its balasmic vinegar but a really really really sweet version. First time a lambic has made me pucker from sweetness. Almost a liquid prune taste as well. Very unique, just not for me. A sweet oud bruin?

Bottle.
Hazy brown pour with frothy off white head.  Smells fruity and sweet - more of the same flavor with some tartness.  Not bad, makes me want to try more of the style.

My first lambic, Im doing it side-by-side with Lindemans Faro. 12.7 oz capped and corked green bottle, no date. Cork says " De Troch Wambeek".

This one looks better. It pours with a bigger head that is also slightly darker. It recedes in odd intervals leaving no lacing. The beer is a bit browner and hazier than the Lindemans with hues of magenta when light-struck.

The smel is quirky it definitely has a funk to it, though not the funk I usually associated with this beer. It has a must to it, maybe some brie cheese, also definitely some major oak in the scent, it also smells very sugary.

The taste is super sugary, with some rotten fruit taste, a hint of sourness (but way over powered by sweetness).

Very, very blunt this one is.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-09-2010 03:43:02

DØE festival, Aarhus, DK
Bottled taster, 271002.
Amber with white head. Aroma of fruit and sourness. Flavor tangy with cane sugar ciderness

Bottle: Pours a dark brown color with a nice little head. The nose is sweet and fruity with a funky rotten wood note. The flavor is sweet with a balancing sweetness along with some bright wood notes and chewy caramel. Big finish and nearly a bit cloying. Not high expectations of Chapeau, but its pretty good. Now on to the geueuze!
13th July 2006  Warning! Early amateur rating! Sweet generic fruit offset by slight vinegary and acid notes. Nice.
brown coloured body with a off white head a sweet fruity sour aroma a sweet candy fruity sour taste with a fruity sweet bitter finish
Hazy brown coloured beer with smal white head and only few carbonation visible. Fruity sweet aroma with a sour touch. Full slight sparkling palate. Finish is sweet fruity and sour.

12.7 oz bottle pours transparent brown with quickly fading off white head. Aroma is cider vinegar, caramel, sour, and cherries. Taste is very sweet, not what I expected from aroma, sugary, tart apple, wood, cherries, and slight sourness on finish. My first Faro, very nice.

Bottle 25 cl from Bier-Bienne (CH). Dark beer with fleeting foam and beaded low. Nose of apple, cider, syrup, woody and sulphur notes. The mouth is perfumed, very sweet, with apple and cereals. The acidity is generously coated with candy. A little sticky and balsamic notes.

Pours a beautiful, clear, light reddish with little head and carbonation.  Aroma is hard to describe, almost like the beer is slightly off/past its due date.

Taste starts off very sweet at the front of the mouth, and stays there.  I cant really detect any malty or hoppy taste, it almost seems like fruit.  Hmmm.

A: The pour is an amber sort of color with a minimal off-white head that dissipates quickly.

S: A chemical/solvent aroma right off the bat with an intense candi sugar aroma and some sweet dark fruits.

T: The flavor has some decent dark fruit flavors in the form of plums, prunes, and figs, but again the same chemical character. A bit of cork, too.

M: The body is medium with a low to medium level of carbonation.

D: This beer could have actually been pretty decent if it wasnt for the chemical nature of it.

Thanks to hopdog for the bottle.  Pours a murky brownish amber with a smaller bubbly creamy off white head. Aroma of oxidized malt, brown sugar,  leather, tobacco, light vegetal notes, very musty, cidery, cork, light funky notes, nuts and toffee.  Flavor was sweet up front, apple cider, light sour and funky notes, brown sugar, nuts, toffee and tobacco.  Too sweet for me and not enough sourness coming through.  Dont really know the style but Im now interested to research it a bit more.

Bottle - Figured Id try a faro, though based on what Id read this wasnt a style I was too hyped to try. It was about what I figured itd be. Rosy and clear, with a tiny white bubbly head. Smell is rotten cherries with metal and apple juice. Real sticky sweet, with a little tartness hanging around. Taste is light balsamic vinegar with overripe apples and rotting fruit, with that same sticky sweetness. Feels lightly sticky and oily in the mouth, with an overbearing sweetness. I dont think I ever need to try another faro again.

Best By July 2011; Sampled July 2010
A full pour summons forth a fingers worth of, dark tan colored head that dissapears fairly quickly.  The beer is quite dark colored, even for a Faro, with a concentrated amber hue.  It shows a brilliantly clear, dark amber hue when held up to the light.  The aroma smells oppressively sweet and of oxidized fruit.  There are some dark, oxidized caramel aromatics here as well (almost cola like some how) as well as some sweet-cherry like aromas, perhaps some raisin like notes and even a touch of lactic tartness that is just noticeable towards the finish.  This definitely smells over-poweringly sweet.

Very sweet tasting, the finish reminds me of cola and sweet tea, both accentuated by a light lactic acidity.  This is nice and light up front, though there is enough sugar here to make it stick to the palate; it is not like malt though that really clings to the mouth.  This tastes like sweet tea flavored with fake lemon and oxidized apples.  Other than the hint of lactic character, you would be hard pressed to know there was Lambic here.

The aroma on this one is definitely a bit objectionable because of the excessive sweetness, the flavor isnt quite as bad, but it is not something I really want to try again.

Bottle. Pours brown with a beige head. Sweet/lightly tart aroma with some fruity notes. The flavor is almost sugary sweet with some fruityness and a light tartness. Very drinkable, and enough complexity to be interesting.
UPDATED: JAN 25, 2016 I liked this well enough. I know faros are supposed to be sweet but this had a little too much candy taste going on.  Serving: Bottle

Tasted from bottle purchased at Binnys Lincoln Park.  Pours a muddy brown-orange with an average white head that recedes to decent lace.  Nose of nutty brown sugar with some funk and a smell similar to rye bread.  Flavor is caramel with some toastiness, light funk, moderate sour flavors, and nuttiness.  Body is medium with average carbonation and a short sour and nutty finish.

Very deep amber, some white skiff. The aroma reminds me of a very sweet version of a flemmish sour. Fragrant, some locker room sweaty lingerings on deep snorts. Sugar, sour cherry with raspberry, just that bit of funk makes this interesting. Warm slightly spicy sweetness and vinegar. Just because this was more complex smelling it doesnt mean that I like it better than the St. Louis one. I really do not like the taste of this concoction. Neat back of the throat burn? That is odd but there is waaay too much acidity here.. vinegar. Ill say that what I think the spice is would be vinegar... is that even a sentence? Odd dark and sweet fruit, strong candy. Way darker than St. Louis. A slick beer. Maybe this was a bad bottle but maybe not. This was less than enjoyable.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2012 Bottle thanks to Wedgie9. My first "faro" rating. Pours a muddy brown. Nose is musty sour dark fruit. Taste is butterscotch candy, sweet caramel, dark fruits. Very sweet with some sour. You either hate or love it. I understand most people hating this. You got to like the sweet stuff to like it. Their beers taste like caramelized candy.  I really love this brewery. Most people dont. Thats fine with me. Send De Troch my way if you dont like it.

Dark brown body with zero cap. Overly sweet honey aroma with some vinegar. The vinegar continues in the taste with sour cherry, more vinegar, maybe raspberry, and a flavor that reminds me of the mix between root beer and orange pop. To conclude the is vinegar with sugar added some cherry. The End
UPDATED: MAY 22, 2010 Fruity nose, apples, pears. Sweet malts on the palate, cidery, apples, mildly sour and acidic.Finish is fairly sweet. Its not a challange beer.
Clear dark copper body. Begie head. Aroma is little yeasty and "rubbery". Also sweet. Flavor is sweet(!) and has some "rubbery" feel as well.

Bottle from 2-be in Bruges. Pours dark amber with a slight off-white head. Rather strange sweet/sour aroma. Medium plus body with mild carbonation. It is sweet/sour. Maybe a bit of oak in the finish. Sweet/sour - back/forth. Finish is towards oak astringence. Overall I think I like it.
Bottle.  Brown pour with almost no head. Smells sweet like maple. Also vinegar but mostly sugar. Uber sweet and almost undrinkable.

Bottle courtesy of solan thanks for this awful faro lol.  Pours a pale brune body with a scant bubbly lacing.  Overtly sweet, maple hints, vinegar yet sugary and sweet.  Woody, cork tones, very sweet mild balsamic sweetness, eh.

Bottle: Poured a cloudy dark burgundy color lambic with a small foamy head with light retention and no lacing. Aroma of syrup and sugar is somewhat gross with light oak notes and no funky notes. Taste is also dominated by gross sugar and syrup with limited complexity from the oak or the base lambic. Body is full with minimal complexity and a minimal carbonation.

My first faro, completing all 72 beer styles at last!  Pours a clear brown/red, bubbly, white head.  Aroma is funky, apple, candi sugar (in this beer, this is where the characteristic funk is most prevalent).  The flavor is almost the equivalent of apple juice, super sweet, light tartness, like a green apple tartness.  The finish is apple juice sweetness again, with a small contribution of funk.  medium body, sticky.  Id like to try another faro that may have better achieved the balance between sweet and funk, but it took so damn long to find this one.  Im enjoying this beer well enough, but if I had to drink more than one it would probably give me cavities.

This was my first Faro, so I have no idea how it relates to the style.

The beer pours a hazy brown color with a white head. The aroma is sugary with a lemon tartness. The flavor is a nice mix of lemony tartness and sweetness. Very similar to sweet-tart candy. Thin mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

An interesting beer. I doubt I will try too many more faros due to limited availability, but I thought this was a pretty good beer.

Pours brown, aroma is sour with notes of pencil shaving, mostly flat, the flavour is dull and offensive, NOt very good. Im not sure if this is how Faro is supposed to taste but if it is than I am pretty disapointed.

Bottle. Drove this bottle of Batshit over 1800km. Apparently JUST for the style tick for Faro. I cant believe there is a Faro rated lower than this! Nose is pencil shavings, tart fruit, brett, and good, old-fashioned table sugar. Like from the sugar dish. Sweet, chemically, sugar. Palate is almost undrinkable. Id rather have a snifter full of Buckleys. Candy, raisins, spolit wine, and good god the raw, unrelenting sugar! So sweet it hurts, I cry for the beer this might otherwise have been.

(gn-btl gn/br-lbl, Brourij De Troch in Wambeek, 12.7oz, 4.7%)

lct-br, thin-ring-hd, 

sour-wine §cider-vinegar aroma, 

sour/sweet T1, sweet cidery T2, eff sour fruity §tart(granny smith) T3.
very drinkable, great with food.

Pours a burnt orange with no head. The aroma is decent, straight forward, with stink feet, stank, and lacto. The flavor is unbearably sweet! This tastes like pure sugar water with a hint of sourness, This is pretty gross... Never again.

Pours an unattractive brownish orange color with no head. "Garbage juice" was a common description of the aroma at the tasting where this beer was had. Garbage juice and herbal bitters, maybe some hobo. Oddly intriguing nonetheless. Flavor is sugary fruit punch with only a hint of the gross herbal note from the aroma. Why?

25cl bottle thanks to irishboy.   This momentous beer marks the final installment in my quest for every beer style category on ratebeer.   There is a reason that this one is so hard to get; it sucks, therefore no one bothers distributing it anywhere near me.   Downright muddy, murky looking amber color with a small head.   The aroma is like some weird veggie salad that has rotted a little, or the juice that collect at the bottom of the garbage can.   Well, its not *that* bad, but its far from pleasant.   The flavor is certainly better, with a big candy sweetness and herbal, almost bitters-like flavor.   There is some tartness in a vaguely pickle juice fashion.   Light bodied, mildly fizzy.   Im sure the more renowned lambic brewers make better versions of the style than this garbage, and I hope that this isnt my last encounter with it.
Ridiculously candy sweet with a woody barrel flavor. this is thick and a little nauseating. I feel like if I drank the whole bottle, Id have diabetes. Bottle from Knightly Spirits, Orlando.

A murky brown beer with a murky head. The aroma is like rotten fruit, & oddly tomatoes. The taste was like apple juice just a little sweeter. Hmm tomatoes for aroma & apple juice for taste is not what I was expecting.

BIG thanks to SoLan for this one and helping me get all of the styles!  Smells like rotten apples and tastes like apple juice.  Quite sweet, a bit sour - my friends loved this but were disappointed it was only 4%.  Cant wait for more faro in the future.
Gold. Just a bit of off white carbonation that dissipates quickly. Tastes like a combination of tart apple juice and sweet iced tea. Medium body, light carbonation. Need to try more of this style.

Bottle thanks to Beerlando!Pours transparent tan-brown, light cream-beige head. Slightly sour cork-ridden nose of sugary fruit and light earth. Flavor is quite sweet, but the fruit (strawberry ?) adds nuance despite being syrupy. Also light caramel and hints of cork into the somewhat lengthy, sour-fruit finish. A little too syrupy and definitely on the sugary side, but way better than I expected, somewhere between the Lindemans Ive had and real lambics. The flavor, despite the sweetness, actually has some nice combination and balance.

i finally found a faro lambic after 1900 beers!  now i can die peacefully.  the elusive faro pours a murky brown with a small creamy off-white head.  dark fruit (raisin, prune,) with a bit of sour in the aroma.  interesting palate of sour and smooth and sweet....weird.  i like it.  flavors of sugary syrup, lots of prune, maybe a hint of cherry and raisin.  low acidity.  i am amazed at how much i like this.  i need more examples immediately!!!

Bottle.  Pours hazy brown with a small, fizzy, off-white head, diminishing with spare lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, hay), light hop (flowers), average yeast (earth) with notes of cherry, sugar, and cork.  Medium bodied, thin texture, light carbonation, and an astringent finish.  Long duration, heavy sweetness, moderate acidity, and light bitterness.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy amber with a medium frothy off white head that lasts awhile leaving good sticky lacing on the glass. The aroma is a strong vinegar and tart. Thin mouthfeel with a sweet fruit taste with apple with a sour finish. My first Faro and was pleasantly surprised by this one.

from secret santa Really beautiful pour. Clear reddish amber with a thick rich head. Vinegar aroma. Extra sweet in flavor with vinegar. Nice body. Really, really bad flavor though. No bitterness almost an apple cider taste.
Bottle. Clear brown coloured with a nice lacing off white head. Aromas of prune juice and sugar. Flavours of sweets, raisins and caramel.
A Mes rate. Draught at ZBF. My GOD this is bad. Ugly dirty brown colour is the best thing about it. Its like drinking sweet dishwater and its pretty horrific. Avoid at all costs...

Well, Ive delayed this for a long time, but Im finally braving the dreaded Chapeau to get my faro lambic tic. The pour is a dark and lightly hazy garnet color with a minimal, khaki colored film at the head. Not a spot of lacing marks the glass. The nose is downright nasty, notes of moldy wood, foul cheese, an dirty feet funking up an underlying layer of malty sweet raisin and soured fig. Woof! The flavor is sweet and funky, probably more heavily sugared than any lambic on planet Earth, with notes of caramel-fig and spoiled dark fruit lending a very saccharine overtone.  Funky, cheesy lactose sourness seems to be more oude bruin/Flemish sour than lambic. The wood flavor is again moldy and musty, and not "good" lambic musty. Sugary sweet and soda-like on the palate, this just doesnt sit well at all.  Its not as horrible as the wretched Chapeau X-mas Geueze, but its not too much better either. Somebody get me a respectable faro to try, stat!
Brown with a lasting off-white head. Aroma of citrus and sugar, with a hint of cardboard. Sweet caramel and wort flavour, slightly tart with a touch of applejuice

Bottled(250ml). -Dark amber coloured, small white head that went away fast, sugary white wine nose with touch of butter. Bitter-sweet sticky fruity caramel taste with quite tart finish. Not so pleasant beer.

Bottle at the Belgian Brasserie Henry, shared with ogivlado. Poured a hazy very dark red body with almost no head. Buttery nose, sticky sweet fruity taste, caramel, figs= Dry near the end. Ok in a way but ho-hum really.

Bottle, from Charleston Beer Exchange. Pours transparent brownish orange, with a medium sized tan head. Mild sweet tart aroma, with mild fruit and floral notes. Flavor begins with wood and a little tartness, but is then overcome by sugar water. This basically tastes like a saturated sugar solution. Syrupy mouthfeel. Finishes with a lot of sugar, a little woodiness, and mild spice. This was the first faro Ive seen for sale on US soil, so I had to pick it up.

Bottle. An odd dark amber/brownish color with a fairly good sized tan head and rather good lacing, actually. Aroma dominated by funk, along with bread, sour cherries, and a hint of sugar. Flavor - damn, is this a ridiuculously sweetened lambic. Starts with sugar, leads into a little cherry- or apple-like fruitiness, and finishes with sugar. I swear Im nearly able to feel the sugar granules go down at the end. Its... not awful. Its no lambic, either. I can see what they were going for in this - an easily drinkable "beer." Its just that it doesnt have enough beeriness, enough sourness, enough funk, or enough of anything else to match the near-cloying sweetness of the sugar. Still, though, I know some friends who would love this one - non-beer drinkers, all of them.
25cl bottle @ Biertempel, Brussels. Pours dark brown with a off white bubbly head. Sweet caramel, earth,  citrus, sugar and dust. Medium to thin palate. Ok.

Deep slightly hazy amber coloured body with brown highlights and a very thin tan head. Aroma of sweet, tart, fresh sugar along with some light hops and a bunch of tart cherries - nice! Medium-bodied; Super sweet flavour of sugar, light citrus and even more sugars. Aftertaste has a little hop flavour, some malt, but mostly sweet sweet fruit. Overall, way too sweet and not enough complexity to rank with any of the real faro lambics. I saw this and figured I should try it, but Ill try to inspect the shelves better next time! I sampled this 33 cL bottle purchased from Beer Mania in Bruxelles, Belgium on 17-November-2008, sampled at home in Washington on 29-May-2009.

375 ml bottle from a trade with the cheesman. amber with a mid white head. the body was pretty still. nice aroma of syrup, cider, sweetness and funk. very sweet flavour, some funk not enough lambic left to make this enjoyable. very sweet, cloying, not good. at least ive had a faro.

Bottle shared with matt7215 at his place, thanks Matt, and thanks Cheesman for hooking up some lambic-starved Ontarians with some awesome beers. Too bad this particular lamic kind of sucked. Pours a murky burgundy with a tiny beige head. Not very nice to look at, and the aroma is even worse. Excessive syrup, cane sugar, candi sugar, residual sugar, and just plain regular unnecessary SUGAR. Some dry funk that is not at all as interesting as funk Ive experienced in other lambics. The flavour is barely passable as a consumable substance. Ronchy funk sourness (very minor) follows rich, near cloying sweetness, totally indistinct and not enjoyable. Gets worse with every sip. Still, glad to have tried such an obscure and semi-unnecssary style. I cant imagine the though-process that went into the invention of this style, "Hey, lambics are awesome! We make amazing beers, unblended, gueze, and fruit, maybe its time we made something that sucked! How can we ruin this product? Add SUGAR!". Whatever.

Bottle thanks to lb4lb.  Aroma has notes of sour white fruits, citrus, apple, and lemons.  Muddy brown with a very slight green tinge.  Small mostly diminishing white foamy head that left some lace.  Flavor is sweet and sour with a heavy lemon and green apple tone.  Palate is medium bodied and lively.   I thought it smelled great but the sweetness and lemon/green apple flavor didnt work for me.

Light brown.  Quite muddy looking.  Smells like oxidized malt, with syrupy notes.  Slightly tart and refreshing on the palate.  Hints of lemons.  Quite sugary.  Offputting appearance, but overall a functional faro.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2009 pours as root beer, dark brown and tan at the extremities. difficult to be excited with a first glance at this ugliness.  carb is low, with a good portion of its effervescence caused from a rowdy pour. aroma of mystery fruit and light funk.  very poor mouthfeel, super slick and devoid of enough carb to lift it from rolling flat across the tongue.  very fleeting amount of sourness on the sides of the tongue at the end the taste.  mystery fruit is very sweet, nearly grainy and quickly tiresome.  like a poor fruit lambic, the sweetness overpowers what little yeast funk might exist, leaving almost nothing for intrigue.  mouthfeel and appearance are strictly a failure, aroma and flavor are average only after a large dose of antidepressants. update: shortly after this review, i became unable to finish even the remaining half of a 375ml.  this is my first drain pour out of nearly 300 beers. it then left a horrible stench of unprocessed sugar emanating from my sink that lingered even as i attempted to wash it away. this beer is horrid.

Bottle. Cute pop. Hideous muddy sewage brown color. Aroma of fruit candy, musty closet, and even has some sweet malt notes. Body is thin, and juicy. Very much like a kids drink, something to put into a sippy cup. Very fruity flavors that are quite interesting. There is a mild bit of natural tartness but the high amount of sucrose-like sweetness overpowers the lingering acidity. Musty, adding character. Decent but extraordinarily sweet.

Dark ambery color, minimal opalescent body, small off white head what diminishes quickly. Must and grapes, some cherry in the aroma with some sweet acidity, minimal barnyard. Fine sourish flavor with a balanced fruity sweetness of must and grape, some cherries, some vinous tannin. Light balanced carbonation. Fine fruity aftertaste.

Bottled (from lahoublonniere.be). Deep ambery brown colour with small beige head. Aroma is sugar, some slight fruityness and a bit of sourness as well. Flavour is sourness, wood and some slight sugary notes as well as some sweet spicelike touches. Quite interesting.

Deep amber, muddy brown color with small fizzy head. Cherries, sugar candy in the aroma with some sour, acid overtones.
Sweet mouthfeel with cherries, peaches, sugar candy, and some barnyard character. Tannic acid aftertaste with slight cider tartness. Smooth bodied with soft, natural carbonation.
Bottle. Pours brown with a one finger head. Aroma is sour, with notes of barnyard and cheese. Tasted fruity, with some leather, cherries, and funk with a nicely syrupy mouthfeel.
The smell is like teriaki, wood, sweet, fruit, and weird.  The look is cloudy, muddy, nice off white head, and amber in color.  The taste is sweet, candy like, caramel, and wood.
Bottle. Almost no head. Sour wine, vinegar and cheese aroma. Flavour starts very sweet. Cherry middle. Shocking sour finish leaves a strong cheese note on the tongue.
Brown in color with a medium white head. Aroma is of wood, caramelized onion, barbeque sauce, and a light sour smell. Taste is sweet and sugary with notes of wood and tangerine.

Sampled at Zythos 2009.  Worst beer of the weekend by a clear mile.  Oh wait. the  Cara Pils was in fact just slightly worse.  Very dark brown, thin off white head.  Its brown sugar, a bit of malt, diluted in water.  Quite comically bad.
Bottle. Clear brownish colour with a small off white head. Sweet aroma and taste of caramel with sour notes. Sweet finish.
Bottle. Small head with medium duration. Color is dark amber. Aroma and taste are sour bread, malt, caramel, honey and cheese.
Bottle. Frothy white fair fully deminishing head. Powerfull not very plesent sour aroma. Very sweet not sour flavor. Moderate barnyrad finish. Oily palate.

Consumed at Zythos, St Niklaas, Belgium, 08-03-09   This came courtesy of Ian and Mes who were on a Brouwerij De Troch tasting mission, cheers lads. Pours hazy brown orange. Plenty of unrefined brown sugary aroma kick us off. The taste has a soft carbonated canned drink feel about it, maybe Dr Pepper. There is a little sharpness but the sweetness is too much for me Im afraid.  A5 A4 F5 P3 OV08   2.5

So this was a big surprise from John via Suds, due to a tasting with Shawn. It just happened to work out that way, and Im glad it did- what a delightful beer! Pours a cloudy orange colour with a consistant battle of sour and sweet- although not forceful- green apple, fig and brown sugar notes throughout. A little bit of tea- something that reminds me of some throat tea that brittany gives me. floral and fruity with fermented fruits. Awesome, and interesting- i would love to try this again! Thanks John!
Bottle from Knightly Spirits.  Hazy brown color.  Aroma is sweet and fruity.  Flavor is totally like a sweet tea mixed with a bit of lambic tartness.  Solan you described this exactly right.

Bottle from Binnys Glen Ellen.  Brown color with a sweet and sugary aroma that has some nice woody sourness mixed in.  Flavor is very sweet with pineapple, brown sugar, and mild woody-yeastiness.  Nice sour/tart finish.  Not bad at all - And I have all styles rated! (Except for sakes)

12.7oz bottle-pours an off white head that bubbles with some lacing and cloudy orange/brown color.  Aroma is wood/vinegar, sweet medium malt, apple.  Taste is sweet apple/cherry/sugar, medium malt, faint wood.  Nice mouth feel.  Mild effervescence.  Taste was quite a pleasant surprise after an average aroma.  Thanks to Armock for the trade with jwc215 & me.

Mission accomplished! 72/72 styles. 350ml bottle cap & corked. Freakin cork fell in. Lots of carbonation, Poured a dark dirty brown, fluffy head which remained till the end. Smells like apples, honey, yeast and cadies. Taste is of apple cider, surgar and champagne? I dont know what was up with that. Finish is sweet and tart, a bit overdone with the sugar. Overall I enjoyed finishing off the styles, as it was one of my beer goals, but this "faro" was a beer that wasnt all that.

I cant say that I really know what a Faro is supposed to taste like, however, as a beer this was not that bad.  Pours an unclear medium dark brown with a small white froth.   Aroma is very sweet, notes of honey, vinegar, dusty yeast, however, not very sharp.  Very sweet and a bit nutty, vinegar, condensed milk, powdered sugar, lightly acidic, but overall sweet and sugary.  Strong vinegar finish, roughly acidic.  Syrupy with light carbonation with small very tiny sharp bubbles.
Pours an ugly brown into the glass with minimal head.  Aroma is dominated by a cider like odor with minimal funk.  Taste is somewhat acidic followed by cloying sweetness.  I drainpoured this one.

One of the ugliest looking beers Ive ever seen. Its a kind of a sludgy brown, little bit of a ring around the glass. Aroma is tart and vinegary. Flavor is a lot sweeter than the nose suggests. Basically, like someone took a lambic and dumped a bunch of sugar in, which I should have expected because thats exactly what a faro is. Overly sweet. Almost sickeningly sweet. Cool to try the style, but I probably wont buy this again.

12.7 oz bottle-Trade w/Dchmela-who deserves great thanks for allowing me to complete my last style-cloudy golden color w/a slight carbonated head & good lacing. Very sweet aroma. This stuff has a really sweet, crisp, fruity flavor-green apple, lemon, & sweet tarts or smarties candies. Really curls the tongue, but not in a bad way. Had a lot of carbonation as well. Very champagne like, did kind of bring to mind a mimosa or an overly sweet Belgian brew. I wasnt really sure what to expect on this one, but I enjoyed it, nice before/after dinner drink. Id drink it fresh to get the best taste out of it, I dont think this would cellar well, probably why the reviews are all over the place on it. Thanks for this one Dave-72/72!

Bottle from Sams Clybourn. Not my last style, but a new one! Pours a deep ugly brown with fizzy, disappearing head. Nose is oak, little vinegar and acid, some apple and lemon. A touch sweet. Taste is a little disturbing, intensely sweet (which I guess I should expect). Tastes kind of like the base beer for Belgian Red, actually. A little sweet apple and some raisins, kiss of sweet cherry. Not horrible, but it definitely is cloying.

Like a lot of people it seems, this completes my beer styles... 72/72. Woot! Corked and capped 375 mL bottle courtesy of mar. Thanks! Shared with cdumler and Alraomon. Pours a strawberry red color with a small head. Average head retention and lacing. Aroma is a quite unpleasant mixture of mushroom, mustard and vinegar. Taste is caramel, sweet and sour sauce and some earthy notes. Full bodied.

12.7 oz corked bottle. MY 72nd OF 72 RATEBEER STYLES! Poured into a goblet, shows murky brown with a half-inch head like frothed milk. Smell is sweet, with some hints of oak and a tiny bit of brett bringing in a cherry whiff. Nice, Taste is good and sweet, like a cherry and strawberry juice mix. Just enough tart to make the sides of my tongue curl. Spritzy all the way through, like a mimosa. Lots of fun to drink. Maybe because Im enjoying this bottle soon after I got it, and not cellaring, but I like this a lot more than the average ratings would suggest. Im happy to have found that this final style is actually quite tasty, and surprised theres not more of it around.

(12.7oz green bottle) Purchased at Brewery Creek in Vancouver, late-November 2008. Pours a thin, quick dissipating head with a clear, deep copper body. Nose of fermenting fruit in a kitchen composter. Surprizingly sweet with cherry, very medicinal. Some prune juice mixed in. Pretty gross. 7/2/4/1/9
deep chocolate brown pour that is kinda murky.  very sweet/tart/almost sour nose.  quite easy on the palate with a big candy flavor.  very sugary finish with a hint of cherry.

Bottle. Nose is sweet candy/fruity with minor sour notes. Dark red with a bubbly off-white head that laces nicely. Sweet and sour yet bland flavor. Sugary cherry lolly pop. Cloying and unnecessarily thick.

Bottle courtesy of Ibrew2or3. Thanks! Pours a light brown color with very thin head, little retention or glass lacing. Aroma os balsamic vinegar, potent sourness, some spice, maybe slight notes of phenol. Flavor is sweet and syrupy with a vinegar and ripe, tart cherry fruit flavor. Generally light to medium body with a very sweet finish.

Deep copper body with a light khaki and white head. The aroma is sweet and sugary with some pears. There is also some decent woodiness along with a little bit of cinnamon. The taste is very sweet, like someone poured sugar into a cherry cola. There is some cherry juice and a little bit of wood. Actually, if you can get past the incredible sweetness, this is an interesting beer.

Pours copper with gold hues and white head. The aroma has solid cherry and plum fruitiness followed by dank clothes closet and acidic tartness. The taste starts very sweet sugar and cherries and then moves increasingly acidic but does not get anywhere near the level of sweetness being offered. To the finish the tartness attempts to purge the palate but the sweet slick sugariness gets in the way. Wow, sweeter than I was expecting.

Bottle courtesy of Ibrew2or3. Thanks Dave for finaly getting me a Faro rating. Pours a slightly hazy copper with a small white head. Aroma of vinegar, cork, and sugar. Taste is sweet malt, cork, and light vinegar. Medium mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and sweet finish. Not for me.
Bottle: Poured a brown with wurky heavy floaties, the head is light white. Aroma is bitter fruit and winey. Taste is winey and fruit, tingle to the tongue.
38cl, from the brewery, not complex sweet brew, not balanced, clear, small head, nothing special

courtesy of ibrew2or3 ... thanks for bringing this hidden jewel to our attention.
Beer turned out a lot better than anticipated.
Pours amber with beige head.
Aroma had a lot of vinegar.
Taste was just totally different. Sweet, fruity (dark fruits).
The finish is lightly sour.

Thanks to Tim for sharing a bottle of my first ever faro. 375ml bottle. Some acidity and horsiness in the aroma as well as some cork and musty notes. Initial taste is raspberries followed by sweet red wine, vinegar, mustiness, and  raspberries. Sweetness balances out the tartness.

Wow, deep and interesting beer.  Aroma is vinegary with pieces of mold, sour cherry, bitter orange, port (?), and cobwebs.  Flavor is sour, cherry, vinegar, and acid.  This is a complex liquid that finishes dry with a vinegary tartness.

caramel body, moderate tan head that quickly disappears.  aroma is boozy, sour fruit.  flavor is dried fruit, sweet fruit, sugar.  full mouth feel, dry, sweet finish.  interesting, but not neccessarily good.

Pours with a generous, off-white head that sticks around and leaves good lacing. Hazy brown body. Aroma is grassy, funky with rotten fruits, skunk, sugar and candied dates. Tastee is ultra sweet with some rotten fruits in the background. Sugar coated raisins as well. Fizzy and dry.

375ml bottle, age unknown. Pours an appropriately dark and unfiltered honey brown color. Plastic-like brown sugar hone, intensely sweet, with heavy notes of sugared and caramelized apples. Bright and prickly on the tongue with a crystalline sugared texture throughout. Sweet up front, sweet on the back, sweet everywhere, but retains the natural sweetness of brown sugar, and also strikes the palate with a soft acidity that melds well with the sweetness. Full and frothy, chalky even. An interesting faro, and even though the bottle is slightly oxidized (it’s especially heavy in the nose) , it may be one of the better faros out there. I would like to have some fresh draft.

Split a bottle with dm9831.  It had a murky brown body with a substantial white head.  The aroma was boozey, woody, and held some darker berries that added a sugary sweetness.  The flavor was much the same except that the sweetness jumped out in front.  It finished on a dry, funky note.  Actually not too bad.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Wine & Spirits, Downers Grove, IL<font size=-1>

2000 bottle from Kulminator. A dirty dark golden faro with a thick white head. Apleasant strong sweet strawberry aroma, funkey, almost meaty. In mouth, a sweet lightly acidic beer, with light leathery notes, maple. Overall, pleasant and well balanced. Medium bodied. 1.80 Euro.

Bottle from thickfreakness.  Thanks Charles.    Poured into a russian river wine tasting glass.  Pours cloudy orange with a 2 finger tan head.  Nose is light and non existent.  Taste is sweet, somewhat cloying but nonetheless interesting and tasty, every faro I have, and all of them I’ve had have been bottled are different, and can’t say I’ve had a true standout yet.

Bottle pours a dark cloudy amber color with a thin white head that does not last at all.  Aroma is nutty, woody, fruity (plum and dark raisins), banana, and bready.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin with not a lot of carbonation.  Flavor is molasses, sweet candy, fruit flavors, a slight tartness (not really sour), and has a brown sugar finish.  Overall, this is a very interesting brew.  I’m glad I got to try it.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2008 Bottle thanks to mmm///beer. My first Faro! Pours a ruby hue with a medium off-white head. The aroma is quite nice; tons of, I guess you would call this fruity notes, somewhat woody and sour. Very pungent for sure. The flavor is also nice; sweet sugary fruity flavors combined with a woody sourness. Some sweet brown sugar and lots of woody flavor. Very odd, a tart cherry/ unripe fruit flavor but also lots of sweetness. A light creamy mouthfeel. Very interesting and nice. Easygoing and yet it made an impact on me.

Bottle

Thanks to bu11zeye for shipping me this recently.  After the last faro I wanted to revisit the style at some point to see if it was a stylistic problem or just an issue with that particular bottle.  As it turns out this one was several times better.  I don’t know that I would drink these all the time if they were readily available; what I do know is that they may one of the most underrated styles on the site.  If you get a chance to try this relatively fresh snap it up.

Aroma / Appearance - The cloudy rust colored body contained molasses, brown sugar, and oak funk.  Less like a lambic it reminds me of a sour brown.  Whatever you call it is inviting and fabulous.

Flavor / Palate - After a tart beginning the taste of chocolate, banana bread and cherries blends into a sweet mixture.  Much easier to drink than its more sour siblings this is a refreshing and different experience.  If more were available at a reasonable price I would buy them.

Bottle. First, and for the immediate future probably only, faro! Wahoo! I was actually terrified of this beer, thinking it would be a sickly sweet concoction that only gets rated as high as 2.9 because of the scarcity of its style. But my goodness, its not that bad! Sure its sweet, but that dont make it bad! Its got tartness that points toward vinegar, that distinct brown sugar component, edges of tart/sour fruit, all sorts of stuff! Its not a blow-you-away beer, sure, but its a fun one to drink as far as Im concerned.

Bottle.  My first faro!  Pours a deep brown with a small light tan head.  Aroma of sweet sugar, sourness similar to that of a Flanders sour.  Flavor is quite sweet and even sweeter and tart with the finish with some sweettarts candy.  Reminds me of Rodenbach Grand Cru (although perhaps a bit sweeter).  I don’t know if this is representative of other faros, but I liked it!
bottle, amber color, tapioca head that quickly faded, nose is all vinegar, flavor is nice sweet sugars, bottle caps candy and strawberry, nice beer

Knockin out my styles!!! Pours a cloudy reddish brown with a thick white head. Aroma is sweet malty caramel and sour. Taste is sweet lambic, cranberry, with hints of barrel sour. A little sweet and cloying and a very odd beer.

Bottle at Flying Saucer - Houston on 07/27/08. Clear amber body with a large frothy off-white head that perisists with a bit of fizziness. Barnyard and light sour aroma with a bit of fruit. Sour fruit, fairly sugary flavor. Medium body with high carbonation.

Thanks Bryan for helping me to finally get this style knocked off my list.  Hazy amber pour, with a strong TCA nose, otherwise known in the wine industry as being corked.  Musty wet dog, forest floor undergrowth in the nose.  Which blows off after a few minutes, but never really goes away, just loses some intensity.  The flavor is actually quite smooth and not at all what I expected, beings this is my first experience with the style.  Flavor is slightly bittersweet, with ripe apple skins on the palate.  Would like to try another take on the style, and preferably one that is not "corked."

Bottle.  Sour milk, molasses malt aroma.  Pale brown color with slight film of a head -  large amount of flocculation.  Very sweet rock candy flavor with just a hint of lambic sourness.  Very sweet - what I expected given the other Chapeau beers I’ve had but at least it’s not cloying and the flavor is nice.

Pours a hazy dark cola-brown with no head and a sweet lambic smell, light vinegar. Very very sweet taste with nearly no bite to it at all, definitely reminiscent of cola, light cherry & grape. Lightly carbonated. Unique but tastes, ultimately, cheap.

Pours cola colored into a tumbler.  Off-white micro head quickly recedes to skim surface. Sweet & sour aromas.  Tastes like it smells -- like a chinese special.  Interesting mix of sour apple lambic and malty simple syrup.  A little thin, but finishes with a tingle.

Pours hazy brown color with small off white head. Slightly sour aroma with apple, pear, grape. Flavor is sweet and sour apple. Goes down easy. Light to medium body with lightly fizzy carbonation and a dry finish. Good stuff, seems underrated to me.

Pours a hazy a hazy brown with with a small white head. Light sweet and bitterness. Strong malty aromas of rye. Also a bit of apples and sweet berries. Sticky mouthfeel. Soft carbonation with a long bitter finish.

375 ml bottle sent by lb4lb I think, well if you sent it Deniz thanks. Not sure if I just dont know what god beer is but for a beer with 139 ratings and an average of 2.89 I think this is drastically underrated and pretty gosh darn good. Poured a super effervescent reddish/brown with an average size fluffy white head. Aroma of apple cider vinegar (yes I did take that note from chaingangguy), sour notes, honey and flowers. Very sweet flavor of white grape juice, honey and just overall super sweet. I really enjoyed this one and loved the swetness about it.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2013 375 ml bottle courtesy of zinister. Pours a cloudy brown color with a small beige head that holds at 1/4 inch. The aroma is strong with funky brett and some green apples. The flavor is tart and sour with green apples, sour grapes and candied apples. The mouthfeel was just a bit on the thin side. The finish was short and clean with a bit of lingering sweet apple. Overall: A very nice sweet and sour lambic.Thanks zinister.  A recommended pour.

Purchased at Foremost Sunset Corners.  12 oz capped and corked bottle.  Deep reddish color.  White froathy head.  Aroma of sugar, rosewater,  and simple syrup (more sugar).  Flavor is very sweet.  Big sugars.  Some wheat.  True to style.
Weird.  Aroma is sour but the taste is sweet.  Ugly...Pours the color of urine from a guy with a bad kidney stone.  Muddy brown!  Taste is sweet and finishes easily.

Bottle @ <a href=http://ratebeer.com/events-detail.asp?eventID  target=_new>   Zythos Bier Festival 2008, Sint Niklaas, Belgium. Clear medium amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light beige head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy brown sugar, candis, light sour - acidic, notes of wood. Flavor is heavy sweet, light sour and acidic with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. (020308)

Appearance: Pours a simple mahogany body with a white head.

Smell: Some sweetish hints to the aroma of apple cider vinegar and rotting logs. Yeesh!

Taste: The extremely high level of sweetness can do little to cover the vinegar and tainted wood flavor. All of it pretty foul. No, no, a thousands times no!

Mouthfeel: Medium-thin body. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: I believe this is my first faro. Although, if the patent awfulness of the rest of these Chapeau beers is any indiction whatsoever, it wasnt much of a faro at all.
Bottle. Unclear orange colour with a white head. Aroma of sourness, caramel and acidity. Flavour of sweetness, malt and sourness. Very nice for a faro.

Pours a deep amber red color with a little bit of a white head.  Aroma is wet musty wood, but not quite as strong as the other beers.  With some cherry fruitiness.  Flavor is sweet cherry syrup and slightly wet wood finish.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2016 Bottle (ZBF2008)
Orangy-brown, small off-white head. Candiflossy aroma. Sweet and mellow, not unpleasant, but too sweet even for a faro.
Rerate: 330ml bottle (5:4:6:3:12=3.0)
Actually rather nice. One of hte best faros Ive had.
375 ml bottle shared by Tim.  Rusty brown with white head.  Candy like aroma.  Rummy candy sweet flavors.  Very easy to drink.  I dug this more that most lambics that Ive tried.

pours a orange golden color with almost no head. Tiny bubbles in the body with a ring around the head.  Nose is funk, sugar, and maybe a little bit of grapes. Taste is of apples, wood, and wild yeast. Mouthfeel is actually pretty nice and the finish is freshing. Not too bad. my first faro.

375 ml courtesy of Zinister, shared at the csbosox tasting on 3/7/08.  Pour is copper-orange with some soapy egg-white foam around the edges of the glass.  Aroma of big Belgian candy sugar that smells like it is being cooked.  Approaching brown sugar.  Taste is big sugary, syrupy and tart.  Get a bunch of raspberry and cookie dough also.  Finish is really think and coating.  Very long finish.  Dusty, earthy, interesting and a nice break to the night.  Thanks for sending this one my way Mike.

Bottle at ZBF 2008.
Clear amber coloured with a small white head.
Sweet aroma of fruits, wood and glue.
Very sweet flavour of fruits with notes of wood.
Too sweet for me.

From bottle, yesterday @ ZBF.
Hazy dark copper-amberbrown color, little head.
Aroma very sweet, fruits.
Medium body.  Taste sweet, light sourness, fruits.

Bottle @ Yespr tasting.[thank you, BelJohansen]
Pours a hazy copper with a creamy off white head. Lots of particles in the liquid. Aroma is rather tart with a weak caramel background. Okay mouthfeel. Flavour begind funky and tart, then adds wood and good sweetness from caramel at the finish. This is a better faro than the ratings suggest.
Hazy amber with loads of floaties. Sweet and sour aroma with rather vinious and ripe fruity notes. Sweet flavor with light brett notes. Caramel, fruits and wood sums it up.

25 cl bottle, thanks to BelJohansen. pours dark orange with a lacing white head. Aroma is light fruity acidic and sweet overripe fruity. Flavour is sugarish sweet and caramel malty, light acidic note - much like flemish sour. Light woody and towards a light smoked note. Ends with a citric to acidc note. Nice.

I quess Im a sucker for the sweet beers
This poured a clear copper with a nice creamy white head.Smells of vinegar like sourness mixed with apricots.Taste is sweet and sour similar to homebrewed  hard cider with oak and caramel highlights. You have a tartness from the lambic but the addition of the sugar just rounds this beer into a very drinkable dessert.Try it as a intermezzo  at your next beer tasting
Nice brwon tea color with a frothy head.  Overly sweet in taste, but also with a sour iron-like tinge.  Not my choice, but I wanted to try a Faro, so I can noy say I did.
Bottle. Bit hazy golden amber with floaties. Sweet sour caramel fruity aroma. The flavour is sour with caramel, some dark fruits, yeast and wood. Nice!

Dirty watered down cola color with thin frothy white head. Gregis is dead on with the vegetal, sweet and sour balsamic vinegar mixed with weak tea...DEAD ON. Nice sour flavor...baked apples, bread and pear nectar. Good carbonation and nice finish. Good stuff.

Bottle courtesy of lb4lb. Pours the color of dark iced tea, with a cascading, frothy, beige head that leaves creamy lace in its wake. Mildly vegetal and funky, the nose is distinctly sweet and sour like a mild balsamic vinegar mixed with a weak tea; very odd. Light to medium-bodied with fine, tongue-tickling carbonation and a tart, lightly dry finish. The flavor is considerably more pleasant than the aroma. Sweet and tart like a naturally fermented apple cider: mildly funky and tart at the finish. The aftertaste emphasizes an earthy, bready yeast note. I actually liked this quite a bit more than I thought I would after getting a whiff of the nose. If the nose were more pleasant, I could see this beer appealing to a larger portion of the market (but I dont suppose thats necessarily the goal with Lambics). While I have no basis for comparison (as this is my first Faro), Im surprised to see this beer scored so lowly, especially among others in this style. If this is truly the least of the style to be found out there, I must find others to try. Thanks for sending this one, Deniz!

Darker brown coloured beer with a lot of carbonation and an average but disappearing brown head. Sweet sour aroma with some wooden oaky touches. Medium to full palate. Finish is light bitter with a rather sour dry rauch touch. Not bad.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2008 Got this today from hopscotch, thanks pal! 12.7 oz corked bottle Oh my, this stuff is simply delicious, a great beer by any standard. Fine wine aroma. Nice dark clear color. Friendly by any comparable specification. Delicious and perfectly balanced, absolutely no bitterness in this beer what so ever. If this was cheaper and readily available, I would buy it all the time. Its gone? Blast.  What a great beer drinking experience, as good as or better than fruit lambics. I really owe hopscotch one for this!  The finest of fine. In my humble opinion, some of the best beer Ive ever tasted.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle Clear, deep amber ale with a mid-sized, creamy, white head. Good retention. Smells earthy and dank with notes of wood and fresh, warm perspiration (not like armpit more like the aroma of ones shirt or hair while working out). Medium to full-bodied with a whole-milk mouthfeel and ticklish carbonation. Medium sweet with moderate acidity. Kind of fruity, like ripe red apple. Finishes both sweet and tart. Normally, Im totally opposed to a real lambic with sugar thrown in, but this one sort of did it for me sort of.

Bottled. Had this one for a while, but Ive been told that Fresh is the only way to go with this one, but here goes... Poured an Orange color, no head but constaint carbonation rising from the bottom. Sweet, but I was expecting a lot sweeter, some earth and funk to this one, but not bad at all, fruit, pear apple, ok flavor, and I cant wait to try this fresh!!!

12.7 oz bottle thanks to lb4lb, the newbie of the year.  Pours a hazed ruby brown with a small off white head that gathered when swirled.  Great nose on this.  Funky earthy with cherries, and a touch of sugar.  Most of the funkiness is lost on the flavor though.  Cherries, malt, and a straight sugarry sweetness.  Some herbal and sour notes barely detectable  underneath the sugar.  An enjoyable beer though, Id like to try more of this style.

[911-20071205] 12.7floz (w/ PhillyBeer2112). Sour cherries and dark malt aroma wiht a hint of sickly plastic. Clear, dark red body with a long-lasting creamy off-white head. Sweet cherry flavour has a bit of alcohol and a sour finish. Medium body is too sweet but not sickly. Interesting to try anyway.

Thank you to Holdenn for sharing this 12.7oz bottle with me.  Slightly cloudy dark ruby color with medium off-white head and nice lacing of a seahorse.
