Aroma is pretty funky with cherry like sweetness and some red apple.  Flavor and pretty sweet and tame, doesnt really match the aroma except in sweetness, but very nice and drinkable.  Medium body that is semi-syrupy.  Pretty nice.  Thanks Matt!!

Big thanks to theisti for finally delivering me a faro. Now I have everything but the dreaded low alcohol beer. Most clear dark orange color with a medium head. Aroma of sweet fruits (apples and grapes) and vinegar, very much like a sweet cider. Cloyingly sweet taste, syrupy texture.
Dark clear amber pour with a bubbly white head that disappates quickly and leaves a nice white lacing.  Some liquorice and sweet potato.  Some sweet saltine cracker on the taste.

Thanks a lot lb4lb. Pour is a clear burgundy, medium white head. Aroma is sour and like a tamed gueze. Flavor is sour and sugary, not really on the tart side at all just sugary. Apples bigtime very cider like. The aftertaste is very syrupy and cloying which is throwing things off, it goes from sweet and sour to just syrupy in like 5 seconds. Really its more of a cider.

A bit sweeter than what I like.  The sweetness has hints of apple and cherry, but in general covers up much of anything else.  The nose is faint but has the eau-de-barnyard that I love. Thanks to Wil for picking this up for me at World-o-beer.

Dark ruby color. Curious boozy aroma. Brandyish, also with a cheap cherry liqueur quality. It previews a hugely cloying flavor, and while hugely sweet I guess it wasnt as syrupy cloying as Id feared. Its getting close though! Theres a slight cherry pit tartness. Weird herbal finish that hints at anise.

Small serving during 11-30-07 tasting at the Lex-Larp Cellars as I joined joet and the Twin Cities crew. Poured from a bottle. Intriguing, pungent, tart aroma features salsa and apricot scents. Pours an effervescent tan / light brown with peach / off-white head. Tangy taste. Apple cider, apple juice, pear, pepper, and cinnamon flavors. Medium body. Lively and smooth in the palate. This is my first faro, so I dont know what theyre supposed to taste like. It neither blew me away nor was offensive, but Im glad I tried it.

So it seems people like to knock this beer because its overly sweet.  Personally, Im not a huge sour fan...I guess they just dont blow me away.  Not bad, just not mind blowing.  I like the way the sweet sugar and sourness play off each other in this beer.  I can taste vinagar, tart lemon, and some fruity sugar.  I think Faro may be one of my more favorite lambic styles.  I enjoyed this beer quite a lot.

Supplied and sampled at Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul. Pours a semi-clear amber beverage with a fizzy light brown/white head that has good retention. Aroma of tart cherry, caramel malt, brown sugar and barnyard funk with light yeast. Taste is slightly tart pitted dark fruit, a touch of lemon citrus, yeast, and candi sugar. Finish turns from tart to semi-sweet with a caramel and dark berry aftertaste. This is my second faro in three days and is the sweetest of the two Ive tried.

12.7 fl oz bottle for trade with lb4lb:  (Thanks Deniz!)  My first faro.  The ever elusive faro.  I thought it would take me forever to get one of these.  Well, it did but lb4lb got me one.  Now to the review.  Aroma has a very tart sugary aroma to it at first.  With some subtle malts, cherries, and sour candy.  Pours a dark amber with a medium sized tan head that lingers around for a while.  Taste is a lot of sugar that comes right up to and smacks you in the face.  Wow!  Still tastes like sour candy and some lemon mixed in there as well.  On the back end a little bit of roastiness, I have to agree with the reviewer below me.  Its like a mouth full of table sugar.  If this is indicative of all faros then Im not going to go out of my way to get them.  Overall,  Way too sweet.  Glad the lb4lb got it to me, but i guess its just not my style.

Pours amber with a pink string of bubbles around the surface.  Smells of sugar with some elements of funk.  Taste is an aweful combination of sugar with some tarte hints.  Like drinking a mouthful of sugar.  The worst of the bunch.

Thanks to beastiefan2k for sharing - my first, and quite possibly my last faro - smells like raw cane sugar and earthy, almost rotting fruit - not a lot going on in the flavor - sugar dominates, along with some cherry and other fruity aspect - there is some acidity and sourness far in the background, but the sweetness overpowers it so much.
Bottle: Amber pour with an off white film. The aroma is rotted apple. The flavor is sweet and sugary everywhere, with no body to back anything. Vacant palate. Too sugary. This is a miss.

Mmmm, faro!  If anyone knows how to make a sweetened lambic, it should be De Troch.  Dark tan coloured beer, herbal and dusty aroma.  Sweet and sugary aroma.  Very candyish flavour... almost as sweet as the Pertotale I had last week (but not quite).  Quite sweaty and chewy with a bit of rotted/overripe fruit.  There is a touch of sourness on the back of the palate, but they nearly clobbered all resemblance of this to lambic out of it.

pours a dark tan with a good amount of head, lacing is impressive too! ....... sweet smell of fruits and sugar ...... wonderfully tingly on the tongue..... The flavours are the real surprise! sweet, some slight sourness: wonderfully  delicious with fruit, tea, and sugar flavours...

This was a big surprise from De Troch, I loved it!!

Bottle via trade with lb4lb. Only one to go before I hit all styles... Faint sweet ans sour aroma. Brown sugar. A hint of mustiness. Lime zest. Pours dark copper/amber with a quickly disappearing white head. Flavor is mostly dry with some residual tartness. Definite brown sugar mild sweetness. Not too complex, but highly drinkable. Medium bodied with good carbonation. My first Faro. Not too bad. Highly reminiscent of Lindemans Gueuze. Not too complex, but very high on the drinkability scale.

Thanks to the Texas crew legion/lumpy.  The beer pours dark copper, dark enough that one cannot see through it, and kind of reddish in the light. Has a small but sticky head.  Aroma is strong with a wet bark and fresh wet sugar cane sweetness. Definitely sweet, I should have expected it from this brewer but it still took me by surprise.  Taste is a bit better, still sweet but it dies down as compared to the aroma.  Other lambic-like qualities appear in the background, some oak and a faint sourness. Leaves a sugar candy aftertaste. Its not all that bad, if only they could cut down the sweetness a bit.  This was my first faro (as a lot of these ratings will probably say) and I could definitely see why the style was created; an alco-pop for the masses back in the day.12.7oz bottle, cap and cork (which was engorged with liquid), Rodenbach Grand Cru smaller tulip glass.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: My first experience with this style.  Hopefully the last.  Pours a fairly clear dark copper amber, with a thick, foamy off white head.  The smell was really tasrt andacidic smelling, almost of rotting fruits.  The flavor was incredibly sweet.  Not sugary sweet, more like tart sweet and sour sweet.  Not what Im looking for by any means.  Some funky tannins are noticeable as well, but they dont help.  I guess this is just how this style is.  Forgettable.

Bottle. Body-iced tea with a medium ring of bubbles. Nose-urine, light funk, artificial sweetener. Taste-very sweet, unsweet grape, sticky, light funk hidden by the sweetness, strawberry, lightly oaky, peach, medium tart, sweet malt vinegar, apple cinnamon. Intriguing-not all bad, but certainly overly sweet. Has a good base flavor that is just absolutely mouth raped by the over the top sweetness.

Bottle at Delirium Cafe. Pure sucrose/molasses aroma. Lightly vegetal. Sweetness going down, light tartness in the back, banana, peach, green grape. Very sweet, easy going down. Generally a pretty weak faro, but what can you expect from Chapeau.

Odd sour maltiness in the aroma, hints of caramel.  Pours dark amber, almost brown with a thin head that dissipates.  Sweet malts up front, good tartness right behind, malty and caramelly, with hints of apple skins and sour candies.  Surprisingly enjoyable.
Bottle.  Pours like Coke with a nicer head.  Aroma is Brachs caramel candy.  Flavor is strawberry syrup with faint chocolate.  Sour finish.  A bit watery on the tongue.  Very enjoyable.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text:
Can I compare thee to the first time I had sex? Well, only in part - the sex was far better. Just had been anticipating having a faro for a while. Something about this label that I admittedly know litle about gave me the idea that it would likely not be the very best.
I knew that faro had sugar added. Suppose that if the beer was SUPER sour that it might survive. Im not big on sweet, but do love sour. This came across like asweet -tart (the candy). Pear and bla bla bla - if its not going to try any harder to be a good beer it just doesnt inspire me to leave a better rating.
Really beautiful pour. Clear reddish amber with a thick rich head. Vinegar aroma. Extra sweet in flavor with vinegar. Nice body. Really, really bad flavor though. No bitterness.
As expected for the style. Quickly fading head, lots of sour green apple on the tounge with that hint of sweetness.

Poured amber with head, heavy carbonation.  Aroma of rotten fruit and wooden barrel, not very appealing.  Hits the mouth with heavy carbonation, vinegar, and slight fruit flavor.  Finish near non-existant, a little sweet and sour. Was expecting more since their Banana is a personal favorite of mine, let down.

(bottle, thanks JK) Pours light amber with a minimal white head and a large amount of sediment.  Aroma was of apple cider, malty sweet, with also some sugar snap peas.  Tasted very sweet with some brown sugar, cinnamon, and a baked apple finish.  Pretty good.

Many thanks to JK for sharing! The beer had a weak brown color with a fair amount of sediment. Sweet fruit and alcohol were present in the aroma. Nice sweet/sour flavor with a nice sweet fruit finish.

Purchased March 2007 in Brussels, for no other reason than the style is so rare and hard to get, especially in the United States.  I enjoyed this beer.  Hardly world class, and surely the weakest faro I have had, but like all of Chapeaus products, it is very drinkable.  The aroma has caramelized sugar.  A dark brown beer with tons of sediment like all Chapeau products.  Sweet flavor with apple, brown sugar, very light hops surprisingly, just a hint of barnyard, from whatever actual lambic is actually in this beer, and finally yeast.

Many thanks to JK whose supplied all my faro samples thus far.  Sweet candy sugar nose and a clear brown color with faint sedement.  Burnt apple and brown sugar on the body.  Sweet and tart on the finish.

yellow, sweet lemon aroma and flavor, nice tartness

Bottle at home.
Almost ruby with a beige head. Aroma moderate malty(fruity). Flavor moderate sweet and very acidic/fresh. Light body. A pleasure.

(Bottled) Very dark ruby brown with a very small, tanned head. A tiny amount of tartness and oak barrel in the sweet, sugary and dried-fruity aroma. The flavor is mostly sweet-sugary, with some oaky, vinous tartness present. Medium-bodied, sugary-sweet palate with low carbonation. A horribly sugary faro, but at least it has some real flavors present underneath the cloying sweetness.
Not really offensive but not that great either. Aroma was slightly apply malty base hints of sourness but not a good effort really. Taste is a similar ball game.

Bottle at Afspanning, march 07. Strange, green apple, anise, spicy aroma. Strong sour-sweet flavor, strong sugary presence with a sour backbonee and a cidery finnish. Interesting. Medium MF with a strong, flavor profile and a slight dry end. Shinny golden clear color with some copper shades and a small but lasting white head. A sour sweet, inriguing, girlie-bordering brew. Would love to try an authentic faro though.

Botled. Reddish coloured. Unclear. Fluffy brown head. Cold tea, immensly sweet and fruty aroma. Flavour is too much for me. Sweetness, sugar, light sourness. Is medium bodied. Overly sugary end. Man this is not a faro I like.

Bottle 25cl., 1year past bb date. Apple and candy sugar in the nose and a bit funky. Tastes sweet, little acidic, hints of sherry/madeira, apple, lemony and some candy sugar. Finish is fairly short with all of the above. Nicely balanced and much better then expected!

Bottle from Degarth; Date hard to read looks like 02; my third faro; Nose of aplly spices with some woodiness; hazy rust colored with a small off white head; flavor was not all that sweet caramel apple with only a small hint of tartness showing up in the finish as kind of an apple cider vinegar but very light along with some caramelized sugar. Not near as well balanced as the Lindemans or even St louis faros Ive had.

Bottle, 4.75%. 4-5 years past BB date. Gusher. Quite sour aroma with earth and wood. Dark grey/copper colour, slightly hazy. Very small white head. Some black floaties, probably due to age. The flavour is sour and sweet in good balance. The acidic sourness is better than the sugary flavours. Hint of sherry/oxidation.

Deep copper color with a loose bubbled head.  The nose is a complex combination that reminded me of a mix of tequilla, dill pickles and moldy hay.  I am afraid to taste it.  Wow, that is weird.  The rock candy sweetness is very evident, but it is not melded in with the other flavors.  It just seems to be oddly paired.  Vinegar, soured fruit juice, and hints of the horse blanket must and moldy hay from the lambic.  This is all but undrinkable.  It is so different from anything else, but even as I recalibrate my palate it is still one sweet/funky drink.  Thanks to Santa Papsoe for the bottle.
Thanks to sliffy at CTV3.Aroma of old pickles.Pours light brown with a light tan head.Flavor was very sour,lots of vinegar.Medium mouthfeel with a pretty bad vinegar finish.

Looks good: a red amber with a nice frothy head. Aroma of powdery sugar and some pine wood. There is also a lashing of something sweet that reminds me of a lolly Ive eaten some time in the past. A fairly smooth flavour, slightly on the sweet side of a good balance. A nice sour lead off on tasting that is soon couteracted by a sugary rush. Its really sweet (which is expected), but its not at all cloying. Easily drinkable, and also strangely enjoyable. Id love to try some others of the like.

Well, I wondered what a Faro was and now I know: its a lambic for beginners and the sweet-toothed. It has training wheels in the form of a heap of sugar to take the edge off the sour, funky flavours that make lambics so beguiling. This wasnt awful but I cant help wondering how much better it would be without the "20% sugar candy" listed in the ingredients. It was a cloudy caramel colour with a short cappuccino froth. The aroma was dominated by the barrel aging - like fresh-cut turpentine logs. It smelled like a much stronger beer, sherbet sour-sweet and alcoholic with an intriguing mint humbug note. NIce soft mouthfeel with a slight spritz in the swallow. The first sip offers a lovely lemon-sour, woody note before a big wash of sugary sweetness. Geez - this is a sugar bomb. There is a minty mouthwash effect to the finish and some classic lambic sourness but the sugar smothers everything. Nothing against the style - I can see a lot of potential here if the sugar was more restrained. Makes me wonder what the Cantillon and 3 Fronteinen are like. (25cl bottle from trade with Papsoe - many thanks, Henrik, for the chance to tick another cateogry in the Beer Styles list)

From a 330mL Bottle.  Transparent, honey gold pour with a thin layer of quickly dissipating white head.  Light, musty sour aromas of dusty oak and a sugary dose of clover honey.  Some muscat grapes bring a touch of sweet vinous notes as well.  Light to medium bodied, gently carbonated mouthfeel.  Lots of sweet orange flavors and some more muscat grapes.  A small touch of musty sourness comes through at the end, but this brew is mostly dominated by sugar.  Excessively sweet for my palate overall, almost to the point of undrinkability.

Yeast muddle orange and amber, plum fringed, with a rim of white. light aroma of rotting white grapes, with a meaty squeek. Faint lambic edges of oak and sour lactic. Lightly revolting. Sickly sweet white grape candy and some rotting citrus in teh bottom of the fridge dorr. Some dripping honeyish notes, lots of ogrape skins. Far away a grassy wash of lost hop memories. Light efferevesce, but overall destructively sweet and nasty.

Shared by Sliffy at the last Columbus tasting.  (Thanks?).  The aroma was of pickles, gym socks, and flowers.  Light brown in appearance.  The palate was light and flat.  Taste was sugary sweet, earthy and some fruit in there somewhere--all amongst the aforementioned pickle juice.  I prayed to St. Andre for help in finishing my portion, and he answered my prayers...with cheese.

Bottle shared by sliffy at CTV3, thanks! Copper with almost non-existent head. The aroma was pungent to say the least, lots of vinegar...like staight apple cider vinegar. The flavor also was pretty much staight vinegar with some apple cider to it. This one is pretty rough...cheese or no cheese. Looking at some of the other ratings, this one had some major infection.

C.T. 3.0- well, it looked okay. And then I smelled it; apple cider, pickles and feet. Tasted about the same but had a lot of sweetness up front that quickly became sour. Glad I got to try it once, but never again.

Bottle at Columbus tasting 3.0 shared by sliffy! - Thanks! - Pours light brown with very light tan head that didnt stay at all.  Aromas of vinegar, pickles, barnyard, and funk..  Very pungent and in your face..   Flavor is vinegar at first, then some funky barnyard then a little apple and candi sugar there before the sourness finish it off again.  Good thing the St. Andre cheese was there to cleanse the palate cause this one was a little tough to drink..

Bottle courtesy of Papsoe: Copper color with a white head. Aroma, dill and vinegar. Flavor, sweet up frontwith a vinegar, kick, kinda felt like a cider, there was definitely an apple taste to it. Though it did pair well with this St. Andre cheese we had, this beer was pretty vile.

Bottle shared with GregClow, Blankboy, biegaman, and Hogtown Harry, courtesy of Harry.  Im not a ticker or a ratings whore, but I dont mind admitting I wanted to knock off a Faro, mainly to see what the heck it was, and yes, to complete my styles journey. So here goes.  Weird aroma - musty stuff, dust, weird sugar sweetness, some malt, yeast - odd but I kind of liked it.  Dark yellow, small white head.  Eye opening taste - but what is it?  Malt, yeast, so much sugar sweetness, some fruit notes.  It starts interesting but becomes so sweet and ends up tasting like every other Chapeau Ive ever tried.  It odes, however, make me want to try a good Faro.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, biegaman & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Finally the long sought after last style: Faro! Pours a dirty amber with a spare white head. Aroma is sour and funky with some sweet sugary notes -- pretty nice. Cant say the same for the flavour though: what the hell is in there? Its sugary sweet but something seems off, it does not taste good at all. Thanks Harry for sharing this elusive style with us.

Bottle shared with biegaman, blankboy, tupalev & HogTownHarry - courtesy of HogTownHarry. Finally got all the Styles! Yeah! Pours a hazy deep amber with no head. Aroma is pretty damn nice - a good mixture of sweet and sour, with sweet sugary notes hovering over a tart, funky background. Flavour - eh, not digging this as much. The sweetness gets cloying quickly, and the funkiness is all but buried. Still - its the LAST STYLE! Thanks Harry!

Bottle (375ml).  Shared with biegaman, blankboy, GregClow and tupalev, my bottle via trade with Saarlander.  THE LAST STYLE!!!  Well, its capped and corked, the cork was pretty wet, lots of pressure, but no gushing.  Mostly clear amber with large dark chunkies, small head.  Really nice sour aroma, sweet candy malt, funky yeast, rubbery - pretty nice!  Taste is very sweet and fruity, yeast but not much funk.  Thick, sweet, syrupy mouthfeel - ehh.  Smells great.

Best by April 1997.  Thanks Saarlander for picking this up and trading it to me!  The aroma is woodsy rhubarb.  The pour actually looks nice, but only on the first glasses taken from the bottle.  It looks like sludgey poo later on.  The flavor is really sugary.  Sugary woodsy flavor and palate.

Best by April 1997. Last pour of the bottle. Dirty poo water with slight amber hints. Thin bubbly head. Woody/corky whiskey-like malted aroma.  Sugary honeycomb hints. I actually moderately like the aroma. Its aged and woody. Taste is sweet and woody. Burnt caramel. Okay... perhaps a nice introduction to lambic beginners. It is overly sweet, but that does not take too much away from the lambic character.

Bottle shared by Blake.  Hazy orange body, not much head.  Cardboard, wet cork, dried banana, and lactic acid.  Not really inviting but not terrible either.  The flavor takes a downturn - stale, tart sugar water with a woody finish.  Glad to have tried this stuff so I can appreciate unsweetened lambics more!

vintage april 1997 thanks Blake
cork smells like honeycomb and shit.
a copperish color w/ visable carbonation and a nicely full off white head w/ some good lacing (surprising on a beer this old)  Odd aroma very sweet dark burnt sugars dominate w/ some hints of what I guess I would describe as wood or leather.  Palate is oddly carbonated avg volume.  Flavor is very sweet mostly just lightly carmeled over roasted brown sugars then some more sugar some carbonation then a bit more sugar... Im not sure what a faro is or if this is it but this is blah.

21.05.06  Jimmack Invitational 06  As usual, Joeec5 comes through with the highlight of the event, a beauty from Chapeau!  Honestly, I dont know why people are down on this brewery that consistently pumps out quality sweetened lambics...oh, right.  At any rate, this beer, though thinner bodied, was fully coating and never overly sweet, though a bit so.  Tart but drinkable stuff, Id be willing to try it again.  Id never guess this was a lambic if I hadnt seen the label.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2007 375 ml bottle, via Styles.  Ah, the elusive Faro rate.  Who knows how this one will go.  Pours a dark gold colored body with a slight yeast haze.  Head was very small and faded to a thin film immediately.  Aroma is musty and funky with a sugary sweetness and dry green apples.  Slight vinegar notes as well.  Flavor is rather odd, lots of green apple tartness but then a sickeningly sweet burst of sugar attacks the tongue.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied with moderate fine bubbled carbonation.  Only 1/3 of the bottle thru and its getting a little cloying.  Overall, I dont know what to think, so Ill give it the benefit of the doubt.  Id like to try some "real" Faro before I make a decision, but I think Ill have my Lambic straight.

Thanks to Goldtwins for sharing this one at Noogfest.
Bottle, "best before 1997"
I cant say that this one has gone out of date.
Starts with a thin pour, no head.
Sweet fruity aroma.
The flavor is similar, exhibiting a fruity, sweet cider sweetness.
Thin body but refreshing.

thanks to joeec5 for sharing at the jimmack invitational.  sweet fruity aroma coming off a pale gold colored body.  extremely sweet, but the lite body and a touch of tartness at the end made it very easy to drink and the sweetness wasnt cloying or sticky.  i need more samples of this style.
A clear golden beer with a dry fruit aroma. A flavor of grape wine with a slightly weak palate. This baby was very dry and slightly tart.

This lambic Faro pours an orange gold color from a 330ml bottle. Note this bottle had a best before 1997 on it so this sample may be a little old. Small sized white head. Aroma is apples and peaches, Very sweet. A medium bodied beer. Malts are fruity and sweet. Lots of apple flavors, not a lot of carbonation. A little funky and a touch tart, but mostly sweet. Lots of grape, apple and peach flavors. Still very pleasant tasting, especially for a beer that was nearly 10 years past its prime and stored in questionable conditions. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is sweet.

Sampled at the JimMack 06 Invitational.  Thanks JoeeC5 for bringing this back from Europe!  peachy amber color, quick peachy off-white head.  sugary sweet aroma and a little tart.  flavor is sweet like cane sugar, and tart like unfiltered apple juice.  tartish finish.

Bottle thanks to Joeec5 for sharing. Clear golden color with a small white head. Sweet candi sugar aroma with some green apple tartness and wet hay. Mildly sweet flavor that is off set by a cider-like tartness. I thought this would be cloyingly sweet, but it was not and I rather enjoyed it.

Best by 97: Man I love that.  How scary is it that it sat in a store for that long.  Poured a clear deep gold with a thin minimal head.The aroma was lightly sweet but also tart.  Horesy funk but not over the top. Sweet flavor from front to back.  Mild tartness on the finish ut otherwise bland.  No real funk on the flavor.  I would like to try an authentic one on draft.  I dont know if they are supposed to have funk on the flavor or if the sugar is supposed to cover it up but if there was then this would have gotten a fairly decent score.

Sampled at the Noogfest-II, thanks to Larry I think.  Very light orange pour with suspended particles.  The aroma carries sour apples & cherries, funkiness (like a Flanders ale) some sweetness and an apple cider like leaning.  The flavor was simple with sweet and yeasty apple cider.  Thin body.  My wife liked this style of lambic and said she would try others if I could find them.
not very funky, which is kind of disappointing.  has some sweet n sour flavor with some lemon, apple, and white grapes.

(Noogfest2, best by 1997) Off-white head atop particulate-fulled apple juice.  Aroma is medium sweet, sour, white grape, light funk.  Taste is moderately sweet, sugar, grape, melon.  Light-medium body.

Bottle. 2000 Vintage. Amber body. Small whitish head. Nose is candyish but tart and fruity. Theres almost a hint of pipe tobacco and cedar - surprising! Taste is sweet-sour with tart fruits, wood, and a flavor that reminded me of Asian cuisine. Body is light and bubbly but only slightly tart with mild dryness. Finishes with sweet-sour notes, light balsamic vinegar, light wood and tart fruits.

pours a golden/amber color with a small white head.Aroma of yeast, sweet malts, acidic sour fruit, wood, and dampness like a basement. Flavor is sweet, carbonated, with a sour finish, not a fan of lambics, but not too bad.

Bottle best before March of 97. Golden amber with little head, mostly film, tons of sediment, even with a gentle pour. Initial aroma very faint sour/tartness with a huge sugar kick, fades as the beer warms to a huge musty wood character that has a slight acidity to it. Flavor is sugar up front, with woodsy notes taking over through the middle and only a slight tartness in the finish. Not the greatest, but definately better than its average.

Best before March 1997 375mL bottle consumed on 11/25/2005.  Astonishingly highly carbonated.  Plenty, but not exceedingly so, of off-white head is very well-retained atop a clear copper-amber-pale-gold body, with light lacing and initial vigorous carbonation visible.  Aroma of wood pulp, dirt, sandalwood, wet sawdust, cider vinegar, old musty yeast and maybe a touch of vanilla.  Little to no wild yeast, though I have little experience identifying Belgian beers of this age, and I also have no idea the percent of lambic in this.  The flavor is musty, woody and quite cidery, and of course, sugary.  Simple table sugar, or light corn syrup-like in flavor, but actually, not horribly done.  Of course I would prefer it to not be there, as it bullys the other flavors, but its not quite cloying and not syrupy.  Light oak notes are most evident aside from the sugar, while some light acids gather on the finish.  If there is brett here, its very hard to distinguish amongst the sugar/oak flavor.  Finish is lightly tart, just faintly so, with more sugar and a strange, almost vegetal note present, perhaps wet sawdust again.  Mouthfeel is not oxidized that much, nor very thinned out.  Plenty of carbonation, though low and soft, is still apparent, with a wet, slippery sort of feel.  Hmm, I need to learn more about these.

When you pour it out its not much to look at, practically no head, a little sparkle in an undistinguished amber colour.  Sweet aroma with some fruits.  Starts sweet and  with an sour dry finish.  Not a long lasting taste, but easy to drink and refreshing, while being a little different.

(Bottle 25 cl) Dark golden with a small head with a great fizz. Starts sweet only to be relieved by tartness - and then the two impressions blend beautifully into a row of incredibly refined flavours of which nuts seems to dominate my buds. Excellent and several points better than the Chapeau fruit beers. 280598

Tan-foxy brown beer, clear; just a slim plaque for head. Nose as from soured beer, acetic acid; bit raisin-like as well. Sweet-sour, woody, and obvious taste as from candi syrup. Quite true to style in fact. More fruit acids, here, quite fruity in character in general. Still - a tad artificial. Sugar syrup slickness, not much real body. Oh well, not too bad - certainly wouldnt refuse it when offered.

Medium sized large bubbled, light tan head thats short lived though leaving behind some web like lacing. Lightly hazy copper colored brew, large brown floaters settling down to the bottom of my glass. Fruity nose, apples, pears and somewhat metallic. Light body spritzy. Sweet malts on the palate, cidery, apples, mildly sour and acidic, lightly grassy and sugary with a faint mustiness. Finish is fairly sweet but also fairly well balanced out by the tartness. Not as bad as i had expected. A BIG THANKS to Wohlfs for a chance at this elusive( at least for me) style.
Green Apples and Lots of sugar do not go well together. Like an apple pancake syrup. YUCK with a capital Y

Bottled.  A rum coloured beer which looks lifeless in the glass.  Looks and tastes like apple juice.  No real lambic qualities, just a lot of sugar sweetness in the aroma and sickly apply sweetness in the taste.
Weird horrible green apple and woody taste. Sugary as well. Dark copper in colour. Medium bodied. Bad.

Bottle. It wasnt that good, but there was a little bit of interest in it i suppose. Some green apple and musty wood in the aroma. Really sweet palate. Lots of sugary sweetness. Quite flat, dull and woody. Too sweet for me i guess.

Bottled.  Clear amber colour. Not much of a head. Aroma is a weird mix between Sprite and Jägermeister. Pretty sweet, very slightly tart, tastes more like a softdrink than anything else, Sprite comes again to my mind and Almdudler. It´s drinkable, but pretty far away from beer.
Bottled. Dark amber. Aroma of glue and thinner. Megasweet and one dimensional. Odd sawdust flavour. Strange, and as authentic as all other De Trochs...

pours a gold color with a decent looking head.  aroma is metal sweetness with some sourness but very very light.  flavor is sweet and sour with a decently dry finish.  as far as lambics go, this is my least favorite style ive tasted.

Finally a freaking Faro! Clear golden witha  fizzy white head. The aroma is sour then sweet with som earthiness and metaillic notes. The flavor is syrupy sweet with the sourness very much out of hte picture. Not horribly sweet but certainly quite sweet. The body is medium with a dry finsih, at least given how sweet it is. Having never had another Faro I can not compare this one but given how poorly rated this one is I am guessing that I should try another one if possible.

Bottle brought back from Belgium. The bottle neck shattered on opening, but I shall drink anyways..... Sweet and a little malty/fruity. Not as bad as Lindemans, this is drinkable at least. Slightly sickly....

Bottled at The Kulminator, Antwerpen. Tan coloured with thick white head. Cloudy beer with lots of citrus lemon, very refreshing. The bottle was 5 years old and much of the sweetness gone, motto - age your Lambics.
UPDATED: SEP 23, 2004 (Bottle)  Pours a clear golden color with a small white thin head.  Flavor is champagne-like with boysenberries and white grapes.  Aroma is floral and somewhat tart.

Ok, to be fair, I think this stuff was 6 or so years old as I bought it in a shop that is removing its beer inventory.  Pours with nasty looking blackened yeast (sign of age I suppose).  Lots of sourness and vinegar in the aroma ... suprise suprise lots of the same flavors at first sip.  The sugar offsets this a little but its rather too sweet.  Very little to really write about here.  My first faro, and possibly the last.

A sniff at the neck of the bottle before pouring certainly yields a sour manure edge. Pours with a fair sized off-white head that lasts a while. Hazy bronze colour. Unfortunately the more authentic aromas emanating from the bottle dont survive into the glass. It has a woody balsamic vinegar aroma with hints of wine. Very sweet flavour, with cough lozenges and pear drops. Not as bad as I had been expecting, but it gets a bit wearing after a while. Very sweet and not very sour. Definitely not the genuine article - the lack of an authentic base means that the sugar has very little to cut through and it ends up unbalanced. 25cl bottle from beersofeurope.co.uk (BBE date illegible).
What horror! This beer is liquid dextrose. A load of fruit, basically artificial, and sugar. Very sweet with malty notes.
Amber-brown, clear body.  Off-white head, fully diminishing.  Sweet aroma, lightly woodish.  Sweet flavour, lightly sourish.
Special kind of beer. Brown/yellow, and a normal head. The aroma is sour, old tree or something like it. Flavor too sweet.

Pours a fast disappearing white head on a cloudy light amber body. Aroma is very odd and extreme, sweet and mouldy. Flavor is extremely sweet and tastes like root beer which I definately dont like!! This beer is disgusting in every possible way and is definately a top 3 of the worst beers I have ever tasted. YUCK!

funky, almost super sweet alcoholic cotton candy melted on a candy apple...not tart at all though..sweet and stale powdered sugar aftertaste...SWEET.  I dont like SWEET!, i like sour, damn it...WAY WAY WAY WAY too sweet.
I guess that this is the beer for the lambic lover who doesn't want something sour. The addition of sugar gives this brew a nice flavor. This is a simple, easy drinking beer.

an old bottle dated June '97.  Held up well.  Had some of the sourness of the Gueuze but with a much smoother sweetness that was cremy very pleasant.Some Rasperry and grape flavor maybe some vanilla character.  I enjoyed this one very easy to drink

Bottle at The Dovetail, Farringdon, London. Light bronze colour. Very sweet aroma, and  a sugary, Coca-Cola type taste. Smooth in the mouth, with some cherry and some raspberry. Very sweet stuff, with no development in flavour.
Nice light brown head. Amber colour. Aroma; sweet, vinous, old attic? Taste is primarily sweet. Easy to drink.
Orange color. Sugary aroma, cinnamon, speculaas (sweet Dutch cookie with a cinnamon flavor). Very sweet and syrupy with only a hint of sourness. Cinnamon and grapes.

Sampled alongside Lindeman's Faro. The front label had 3.5% abv, but the back label had 4.75%. Chapeau's label is green & brown with a picture of a beer barrel draped with hops and barley - Lindeman's is much more attractive: all black with stylish art deco white lettering. On opening the Lindeman's had more fizz and an immediate strong plummy aroma. Both settle to a brown copper colour with a fringe of bubbly froth - the Lindeman's bubbles slightly larger and more varied. So far the Lindeman's is ahead. On giving both a good sniff the Chapeau edges ahead with its musty sweet aroma, slightly medicinal, slightly licorice, quite perfumey - parma violets; when swirled extra sweetness rises. The Lindeman's has a slight plum aroma; when swirled some yeasty lambic acid rises. On tasting the Chapeau is the more interesting with its sweet and medicinal taste, followed by a soft sweet licorice flavour at the back. However, it flags slightly when the band aid remains in the mouth along with a cloying, clinging sweey coating of the mouth. The Lindeman's is much simpler, and more direct. It is intensely sweet initially, but that soon settles into a balance between sweetness and acidity. The mouthfeel really pushes the Lindeman's into first place. Chapeau has a soft mouthfeel with a barely noticable and soon gone gentle fizz - quite boring. The Lindeman's however has a soft fizzy mothfeel - very gentle like having baby rabbits tickle your mouth. Weee! The conclusion is that Chapeau is a flavoursome and interesting drink, but lacks the fun of Lindeman's despite the fuller and more complex flavours.

The aroma is sweet with the sharpness from wild fermentation but also with som weird notes; is it some kind of flower, elder flower perhaps? The aroma is not good for a lambic. The color of the beer is amber and slightly unclear with a fine head. The flavor is sweet and sour, but without the bite that lambics have to have. It also lacks the metallicness that is carachteristic for lambics. But instead it the elder flower flavor. And the flavor disappears extremely fast. All in all a thin boring lambic. I am puzzled by the ingredient list - it includes yeast???? in a lambic?

Best before date - May 97. Hazy lemony dark orange. Thin, sticky, big bubbled white head. Barely any carbonation. Sour, oak aroma with notes of grape, candy sugar and horse hair. Initially tart, sweet and a bit chalky. Light bodied. Sweetness overwhelms the Lambic sourness and horsebarn qualities. Lingers on as a sticky, candyish aftertaste. Tart and horsebarn like on each sip, then it fades into the sticky sweetness all too quick. Finishes with a ciderish tartness and flash of its musty, old age. Way too sweet as it warmed. My wife ended up finishing it.
A Geuze with sugar. Disgusting!
One of my first faros. Very sweet, a little sour, a little watery.

Dark hazy brown with no head. Light grainy wheat, vinous, plums, raisins and sultanas. Light sour sweeter fruit juice drink body and palate. Very lowly carbonated almost lifeless. Faintly sour sweet raisin juice. Sweet watery finish and after taste. Too much fruit juice character.
funny beer - It starts ang ends awful but between its quite alright. Maybe its because I great new in the faro area
A nicely done sour beer whose sweetness balances it well.  The  finish is predominantly sweet but then this fades leaving a sour overall impression.  Nice with dinner.  Also a fine Breakfast beer.
A typical Faro. Like the others very sweet. Cood be better, could be worse.
